description: The Administering Microsoft SQL Server 2012 Databases exam is designed to be the entry point for Systems Administrators into the world of databases. The course focuses on areas that are required knowledge for anyone responsible for the creation and maintenance of Windows servers running Microsoft SQL 2012. The topics covered range from installing SQL Server to backing up and restoring databases.
name: Microsoft SQL Server 2012 - 70-462
subtitle: Administering Microsoft SQL Server 2012 Databases

episodes.description: The Administering Microsoft SQL Server 2012 Databases exam is designed to be the entry point for Systems Administrators into the world of databases. The course focuses on areas that are required knowledge for anyone responsible for the creation and maintenance of Windows servers running Microsoft SQL 2012. The topics covered range from installing SQL Server to backing up and restoring databases.
episodes.title: Intro to Microsoft SQL
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,025 --> 00:00:08,034
[SOUND].

2
00:00:08,034 --> 00:00:11,585
This ITProTV series is designed
to introduce the viewer to

3
00:00:11,585 --> 00:00:13,620
Microsoft SQL Server 2012.

4
00:00:13,620 --> 00:00:18,320
More importantly, it's designed to
introduce a system admin, to SQL Server.

5
00:00:18,320 --> 00:00:20,870
Now a lot of people are familiar
with Microsoft SQL.

6
00:00:20,870 --> 00:00:23,280
It's one of the most common
database servers in the world,

7
00:00:23,280 --> 00:00:26,540
you see it very frequently used
in a lot of organizations.

8
00:00:26,540 --> 00:00:30,860
But, as a Systems Administrator,
you're not a database administrator.

9
00:00:30,860 --> 00:00:34,150
You don't necessarily know
the inner workings of a database.

10
00:00:34,150 --> 00:00:37,080
But you might be tasked with
the responsibilities of maintaining, or

11
00:00:37,080 --> 00:00:39,590
even installing and
creating that database server.

12
00:00:39,590 --> 00:00:41,980
It's a very common thing to fall into.

13
00:00:41,980 --> 00:00:45,600
As a result, Microsoft created
an exam that was centered around,

14
00:00:45,600 --> 00:00:50,120
not the programming side of Microsoft SQL,
but the supporting side of it.

15
00:00:50,120 --> 00:00:52,430
And that's what this show
is going to be covering.

16
00:00:52,430 --> 00:00:55,510
The exam is the 70-462 exam and

17
00:00:55,510 --> 00:00:59,320
the official title is Administering
Microsoft SQL Server 2012 Databases.

18
00:00:59,320 --> 00:01:03,300
Now there is a sister course associated
with this one that does get a little

19
00:01:03,300 --> 00:01:06,860
more onto the, I don't wanna call it the
developer side cuz you're not programming,

20
00:01:06,860 --> 00:01:10,920
but dealing with the SQL queries and
all that other stuff.

21
00:01:10,920 --> 00:01:13,230
So there is one that gets
a little more heavier into that.

22
00:01:13,230 --> 00:01:16,930
But this one,
is specifically focused to systems admins,

23
00:01:16,930 --> 00:01:21,120
the people who are supporting Windows
Server, who are putting the hardware

24
00:01:21,120 --> 00:01:24,130
servers in the rack and
getting this infrastructure built up.

25
00:01:24,130 --> 00:01:26,880
They may need to bring up
database servers also.

26
00:01:26,880 --> 00:01:30,102
Now you may have an entire staff of
programmers who are ready to jump in there

27
00:01:30,102 --> 00:01:31,599
and start using those databases.

28
00:01:31,599 --> 00:01:35,059
But they don't understand how to
backup and restore the database or

29
00:01:35,059 --> 00:01:39,060
how to do performance tuning of
the database, things like that.

30
00:01:39,060 --> 00:01:41,070
They deal on the development side.

31
00:01:41,070 --> 00:01:43,580
We as System Admins,
deal on the server side.

32
00:01:43,580 --> 00:01:46,585
And so that's what we tackle for
this certification.

33
00:01:46,585 --> 00:01:49,895
Now, if you look at the requirements,
I'll just kinda scroll down here a bit.

34
00:01:49,895 --> 00:01:52,525
You'll see it starts out real basic
with things like installing and

35
00:01:52,525 --> 00:01:53,765
configuring, right?

36
00:01:53,765 --> 00:01:55,904
We need to get a SQL Server up and
running so

37
00:01:55,904 --> 00:01:58,855
we can start to create databases on it and
work with data.

38
00:01:58,855 --> 00:02:02,540
So that's exactly where it begins,
just the initial configuration.

39
00:02:02,540 --> 00:02:05,370
Then, actually creating the databases.

40
00:02:05,370 --> 00:02:06,510
Somebody's gotta make it.

41
00:02:06,510 --> 00:02:10,610
And maybe you're getting a specific spec
sheet from your development team saying

42
00:02:10,610 --> 00:02:11,750
here's what we need.

43
00:02:11,750 --> 00:02:12,990
But often times you don't get that.

44
00:02:12,990 --> 00:02:15,095
They just say, hey,
we need a database server.

45
00:02:15,095 --> 00:02:19,505
So, we bring one up, we create the initial
databases, and we get the system up.

46
00:02:19,505 --> 00:02:21,921
Now we'll also take a look at clustering,
too.

47
00:02:21,921 --> 00:02:24,879
If this is a database that needs
to be up as often as possible,

48
00:02:24,879 --> 00:02:29,171
like high availability, well, we're gonna
need to take some extra precautions and so

49
00:02:29,171 --> 00:02:30,805
we'll see that in maintaining.

50
00:02:32,240 --> 00:02:34,030
It then goes on optimizing, right?

51
00:02:34,030 --> 00:02:36,540
How do you make the database run better?

52
00:02:36,540 --> 00:02:41,910
Anybody can bring up a database server,
but the more that database begins to grow,

53
00:02:41,910 --> 00:02:44,880
the slower and
slower the system is going to become.

54
00:02:44,880 --> 00:02:46,670
And everybody's data is
a little bit different.

55
00:02:46,670 --> 00:02:48,540
So we take a look at some of the tools and

56
00:02:48,540 --> 00:02:51,540
techniques that are available
to tweak that data,

57
00:02:51,540 --> 00:02:55,510
to change the way that SQL Server
performs and get it running a lot faster.

58
00:02:55,510 --> 00:02:57,600
And I've got some stories
I'll tell in those episodes.

59
00:02:57,600 --> 00:03:01,540
You can really make a big difference
with just a few mouse clicks, so

60
00:03:01,540 --> 00:03:03,400
it's some really neat
stuff that's in there.

61
00:03:04,880 --> 00:03:07,020
Once the server's up and
running, we're done right?

62
00:03:07,020 --> 00:03:08,030
We get to walk away?

63
00:03:08,030 --> 00:03:09,510
Well, not quite.

64
00:03:09,510 --> 00:03:11,340
A lot of times we need
to manage the data and

65
00:03:11,340 --> 00:03:13,240
that's what the next section jumps into.

66
00:03:13,240 --> 00:03:17,125
Especially from the standpoint
of backup and restore, right?

67
00:03:17,125 --> 00:03:22,110
It's very, very easy to accidentally wipe
all of the data out of a database, right?

68
00:03:22,110 --> 00:03:24,198
If you give somebody the access
to write to the database they

69
00:03:24,198 --> 00:03:25,600
couldn't really do that.

70
00:03:25,600 --> 00:03:28,950
So we need to make sure that we've
got backups, reliable backups, right?

71
00:03:28,950 --> 00:03:32,740
It's easy for us to restore and
get our systems backup and going.

72
00:03:32,740 --> 00:03:36,930
And then this little section right here
is probably the most important one in

73
00:03:36,930 --> 00:03:40,740
the entire exam objective set.

74
00:03:40,740 --> 00:03:43,910
Managing or implementing and
maintaining indexes, all right?

75
00:03:43,910 --> 00:03:47,400
Indexes will change the performance
profile of your server.

76
00:03:47,400 --> 00:03:50,860
They will make your server
considerably faster.

77
00:03:50,860 --> 00:03:54,941
But, indexes are completely built around
the types of queries people are running.

78
00:03:54,941 --> 00:03:57,402
So we have to understand
the queries people are running, and

79
00:03:57,402 --> 00:03:59,050
then build the indexes appropriately.

80
00:03:59,050 --> 00:04:02,790
There is no one-size-fits-all
index solution out there.

81
00:04:02,790 --> 00:04:06,820
So we'll take a look at how to analyze
your database, see how it's being used,

82
00:04:06,820 --> 00:04:09,370
and build the appropriate index
system to make it run faster.

83
00:04:11,450 --> 00:04:12,830
After that, we've got security, right?

84
00:04:12,830 --> 00:04:14,600
We don't wanna forget about that.

85
00:04:14,600 --> 00:04:17,810
Some of the biggest visibility attacks
that have happened in the last ten

86
00:04:17,810 --> 00:04:20,420
years have all been focused on SQL.

87
00:04:20,420 --> 00:04:22,830
Well, I shouldn't say it that way, right?

88
00:04:22,830 --> 00:04:25,640
When we say SQL, that means Microsoft SQL.

89
00:04:25,640 --> 00:04:29,870
When we say S-Q-L, well that's the
standard query language that's used across

90
00:04:29,870 --> 00:04:33,304
numerous products like Oracle,
MySQL, and so on.

91
00:04:33,304 --> 00:04:35,960
And, SQL injection attacks

92
00:04:35,960 --> 00:04:38,870
are some of the biggest ones that have
happened over the last ten years.

93
00:04:38,870 --> 00:04:40,832
Many of which went against
Microsoft servers, but

94
00:04:40,832 --> 00:04:43,570
many of which went against the Oracle and
the other guys too.

95
00:04:43,570 --> 00:04:47,240
So, how do we secure our system to
help prevent from things like that?

96
00:04:47,240 --> 00:04:49,863
Well, a lot of that is prevented
on the developer's side,

97
00:04:49,863 --> 00:04:51,234
they can take care of it there.

98
00:04:51,234 --> 00:04:54,475
But there are things we can do on
the back end with databases permissions,

99
00:04:54,475 --> 00:04:55,321
log ins and roles.

100
00:04:55,321 --> 00:04:59,902
And other things to eliminate that
accidental activity where people start to

101
00:04:59,902 --> 00:05:03,931
inject commands and to do things
that we don't want to have happen.

102
00:05:03,931 --> 00:05:04,840
All right.
And

103
00:05:04,840 --> 00:05:08,620
then the last part of the exam objectives
is implementing high availability.

104
00:05:08,620 --> 00:05:13,110
We talk about it a little bit in
the maintaining databases section.

105
00:05:13,110 --> 00:05:15,966
But then we get into it down here
as far as setting up a mirror,

106
00:05:15,966 --> 00:05:20,120
getting Always On configured, setting up
failover, and getting that put into place.

107
00:05:20,120 --> 00:05:22,870
So really good stuff to
keep the system online.

108
00:05:22,870 --> 00:05:26,620
These are the tasks right here
that an average system admin that

109
00:05:26,620 --> 00:05:30,280
supports a network that involves SQL
servers are going to be expected to know.

110
00:05:30,280 --> 00:05:32,180
So it's a great set of knowledge.

111
00:05:32,180 --> 00:05:36,380
For a Microsoft exam this is one of
the few ones where I look at it and

112
00:05:36,380 --> 00:05:39,467
I'm like man,
this is all stuff will actually use.

113
00:05:39,467 --> 00:05:43,040
A lot of times there's at least one
module in there where they put some fluff

114
00:05:43,040 --> 00:05:46,400
cloud service or whatever,
that's more of a marketing module.

115
00:05:46,400 --> 00:05:50,118
But in this one, it's really
skills that you'll use, all right.

116
00:05:50,118 --> 00:05:53,580
Now, if you're looking to go a little
more onto the development side,

117
00:05:53,580 --> 00:05:55,613
if you're looking to write SQL queries.

118
00:05:55,613 --> 00:06:00,074
If you wanna learn how to create
tables and set up foreign keys and

119
00:06:00,074 --> 00:06:05,385
relationships like that, well,
the 70-462 doesn't do it.

120
00:06:05,385 --> 00:06:06,505
But if you're looking to work for

121
00:06:06,505 --> 00:06:10,675
your MCSA SQL Server,
there's other exams involved.

122
00:06:10,675 --> 00:06:14,840
The 462 is just one of them,
that's the one that really is designed for

123
00:06:14,840 --> 00:06:15,811
system administrators.

124
00:06:15,811 --> 00:06:21,171
But notice there's the 461, Querying
Microsoft SQL Server 2012, all right.

125
00:06:21,171 --> 00:06:23,380
That is writing query statements.

126
00:06:23,380 --> 00:06:25,680
You actually start to learn
the standard query language,

127
00:06:25,680 --> 00:06:28,160
how to interact with
the data on the server.

128
00:06:28,160 --> 00:06:31,590
How to put data in the database,
how to get data out of the database.

129
00:06:31,590 --> 00:06:34,921
A regular system admin doesn't really
need to know how to do that, but

130
00:06:34,921 --> 00:06:38,560
somebody who's actually DBA,
Database Administrator, would.

131
00:06:39,880 --> 00:06:44,310
And then, implementing a data warehouse
with Microsoft SQL Server 2012.

132
00:06:44,310 --> 00:06:47,540
That's where you start learning
about how to design your tables,

133
00:06:47,540 --> 00:06:50,590
how to work with the data
inside of the database,

134
00:06:50,590 --> 00:06:54,590
how to create views and reports,
how to deal with integration services.

135
00:06:54,590 --> 00:06:58,020
All these extra things that a normal
system admin is not going to work with,

136
00:06:58,020 --> 00:07:00,830
but instead, a DBA would, all right.

137
00:07:00,830 --> 00:07:05,490
So the full certification, the MCSA
SQL Server, is really designed for

138
00:07:05,490 --> 00:07:10,800
somebody who's operating in that DBA role,
who is a database administrator.

139
00:07:10,800 --> 00:07:15,750
But this one that we're doing right here,
70-462, works really for

140
00:07:15,750 --> 00:07:19,375
anybody who has the responsibility
of supporting a server running SQL.

141
00:07:19,375 --> 00:07:23,850
So I think this is one of the greater
exams, one of the greatest set of topics.

142
00:07:23,850 --> 00:07:25,490
Even if you don't take the exam,

143
00:07:25,490 --> 00:07:28,310
the stuff we talk about on
this show is really useful.

144
00:07:28,310 --> 00:07:30,690
It will help you operate
your database environment.

145
00:07:30,690 --> 00:07:35,190
And those databases, for a lot of people,
if you have a database server,

146
00:07:35,190 --> 00:07:40,710
it's usually the core of your business,
and so losing that, right, is a big deal.

147
00:07:40,710 --> 00:07:43,460
It could take your business offline for
hours,

148
00:07:43,460 --> 00:07:46,390
days, who knows how long to
get a system back online.

149
00:07:46,390 --> 00:07:48,570
So having it set up right
from the beginning and

150
00:07:48,570 --> 00:07:52,130
having a good backup strategy are two key
pieces we wanna make sure we have covered.

151
00:07:53,710 --> 00:07:56,530
All right, now our show content
will match up with the 70-462 exam,

152
00:07:56,530 --> 00:07:59,680
so we're gonna cover all the stuff
that's on there like we normally do,

153
00:07:59,680 --> 00:08:01,584
you'll be prepared for that.

154
00:08:01,584 --> 00:08:03,670
If you wanna go on to do the other ones,

155
00:08:03,670 --> 00:08:06,660
we don't have plans in our schedule
right now to tackle those.

156
00:08:06,660 --> 00:08:10,000
But things change over time, so
by the time you're watching this, well,

157
00:08:10,000 --> 00:08:11,740
not if you're watching it live I guess,
but

158
00:08:11,740 --> 00:08:15,170
if you're watching this down the road, we
may have already recorded the other ones.

159
00:08:15,170 --> 00:08:19,424
So check out the library and
see if they're there.

160
00:08:19,424 --> 00:08:26,650
All right, well that's pretty
much my overview of this one.

161
00:08:26,650 --> 00:08:27,525
I'll see you in the show.

162
00:08:27,525 --> 00:08:28,444
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode Don discusses the minimum requirements for installing SQL. Then he walks through the process of installing SQL while examining each of the installation examples. Finally he shows some of the basic options that will be configured for most new deployments.
episodes.title: Install and Configure SQL
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,002 --> 00:00:10,002
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,732 --> 00:00:36,595
Good morning, good afternoon and
good evening and

3
00:00:36,595 --> 00:00:39,135
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:39,135 --> 00:00:42,176
I'm your host Don Pezet
back with another episode.

5
00:00:42,176 --> 00:00:43,140
Actually, wait a minute.

6
00:00:43,140 --> 00:00:46,070
We're not back with another episode,
this is an all new episode.

7
00:00:46,070 --> 00:00:51,292
We are kicking off our new
Microsoft SQL Server 2012 show.

8
00:00:51,292 --> 00:00:53,545
So exciting,
I always like starting new stuff.

9
00:00:53,545 --> 00:00:55,844
Now you might be asking yourself,
wait a minute, Don.

10
00:00:55,844 --> 00:00:58,924
You're not gonna fool me,
I know the SQL Server 2014 is out,

11
00:00:58,924 --> 00:01:00,970
why aren't you doing that one?

12
00:01:00,970 --> 00:01:03,040
And there's a few reasons.

13
00:01:03,040 --> 00:01:08,260
Reason number one is that SQL Server 2014
is out, just came out not to long ago.

14
00:01:08,260 --> 00:01:09,902
I think maybe three or four months ago.

15
00:01:09,902 --> 00:01:11,435
It hasn't been out very long.

16
00:01:11,435 --> 00:01:16,310
And in the database world,
your data is very sensitive.

17
00:01:16,310 --> 00:01:20,852
And as a result, people don't jump to
the latest database server that comes out.

18
00:01:20,852 --> 00:01:22,920
Yeah, they don't jump out
the moment it comes out.

19
00:01:22,920 --> 00:01:26,636
It'll be a couple of years before we
start seeing 2014 in wide deployment.

20
00:01:26,636 --> 00:01:31,907
So most environments today are actually
still running SQL Server 2008,

21
00:01:31,907 --> 00:01:36,620
even SQL Server 2012 is not as
widespread as 2008 right now.

22
00:01:36,620 --> 00:01:41,437
So we're always a little bit behind in
the implementation world on SQL Server

23
00:01:41,437 --> 00:01:45,078
versions and it all stems from
how sensitive that data is.

24
00:01:45,078 --> 00:01:47,291
You need to know your database and

25
00:01:47,291 --> 00:01:52,041
the data inside of it will be rock
solid before you move to a new version.

26
00:01:52,041 --> 00:01:56,725
The other reason is because this data
is so sensitive and because it is so

27
00:01:56,725 --> 00:02:01,253
important, when you move from one
version of SQL Server to another,

28
00:02:01,253 --> 00:02:05,880
you need a high level of compatibility and
so Microsoft ensures that.

29
00:02:05,880 --> 00:02:10,813
The last major change that SQL Server
saw was way back in SQL Server 2005 and

30
00:02:10,813 --> 00:02:15,014
it was really just a change to
the user administration interface.

31
00:02:15,014 --> 00:02:19,670
Prior to that SQL 2000, SQL 7,
that's where I started was SQL 7.

32
00:02:19,670 --> 00:02:24,935
Those older products really work
the same as SQL 2014 does today,

33
00:02:24,935 --> 00:02:30,033
because it's all built around SQL,
the Standard Query Language.

34
00:02:30,033 --> 00:02:31,165
Let's talk about that for

35
00:02:31,165 --> 00:02:33,850
a minute before we dive into
anything specific to Microsoft.

36
00:02:35,000 --> 00:02:39,505
Databases are just really,
really common today.

37
00:02:39,505 --> 00:02:43,540
It's very rare that you find a company
that doesn't use some sort of database.

38
00:02:43,540 --> 00:02:47,802
Think of it like as like in the 70s,
a lot of companies had mainframes.

39
00:02:47,802 --> 00:02:50,150
Well, mainframes really
were just database servers.

40
00:02:50,150 --> 00:02:53,102
Very specialized,
very purpose build databases, but

41
00:02:53,102 --> 00:02:54,998
that's basically what they were.

42
00:02:54,998 --> 00:02:57,130
You put data in and you got data out.

43
00:02:57,130 --> 00:03:00,394
The problem with mainframes,
incredibly expensive and

44
00:03:00,394 --> 00:03:02,299
incredibly complex to support.

45
00:03:02,299 --> 00:03:07,847
So when the idea of simple software-based
databases started to grow in the 80s,

46
00:03:07,847 --> 00:03:12,522
you saw where people said, what we
need is a single way to interact with

47
00:03:12,522 --> 00:03:17,500
these databases, so that we're not
stuck tied to an IBM mainframe.

48
00:03:17,500 --> 00:03:21,099
That's what really happened is most
companies got trapped in the IBM mainframe

49
00:03:21,099 --> 00:03:22,666
world and they couldn't get out.

50
00:03:22,666 --> 00:03:25,850
And IBM, they make good stuff,
but they charge for it.

51
00:03:25,850 --> 00:03:31,031
It's pretty expensive, so several other
vendors started getting into this market.

52
00:03:31,031 --> 00:03:37,379
You saw DB2, which ended up getting
bought by IBM, you saw, oh, Oracle.

53
00:03:37,379 --> 00:03:42,373
Oracle is a huge company in the database
world these days and so they develop their

54
00:03:42,373 --> 00:03:47,470
Oracle series servers and they do
a great job and Microsoft got involved.

55
00:03:47,470 --> 00:03:51,410
Microsoft SQL Server is actually
one of their oldest products.

56
00:03:51,410 --> 00:03:55,573
Microsoft SQL Server 1.0 came out well
before many of the products that you're

57
00:03:55,573 --> 00:03:58,246
familiar with,

01:26:03,960 --> 01:26:07,068
And I'll log in as SA.

1637
01:26:09,831 --> 01:26:13,998
All right, so now I'm connected
to both my default instance and

1638
01:26:13,998 --> 01:26:17,390
my second instance, all right, my test.

1639
01:26:17,390 --> 01:26:21,250
Be careful when you do this because when
you start to run commands, what you have

1640
01:26:21,250 --> 01:26:25,520
highlighted on the left is what's telling
Visual Studio where to run your commands.

1641
01:26:25,520 --> 01:26:28,200
So always make sure you've got
the right thing highlighted.

1642
01:26:28,200 --> 01:26:33,200
I'm gonna modify my test server and I'm
gonna set some memory limits on it also.

1643
01:26:33,200 --> 01:26:36,490
I'm gonna give it a minimum
of one gig of memory but

1644
01:26:36,490 --> 01:26:39,020
I'm gonna set its maximum at two gigs.

1645
01:26:39,020 --> 01:26:41,550
I don't want it taking
more than two gigs of RAM,

1646
01:26:41,550 --> 01:26:44,050
that's the limit that I've applied for it.

1647
01:26:44,050 --> 01:26:47,700
Now my production system
is capped at four gigs.

1648
01:26:47,700 --> 01:26:50,182
My test is capped at two gigs.

1649
01:26:50,182 --> 01:26:53,810
That leaves two gigs of RAM left over for
my host OS.

1650
01:26:53,810 --> 01:26:55,160
That's gonna make sure I get a nice,

1651
01:26:55,160 --> 01:26:58,200
friendly environment with
these two instances running.

1652
01:26:58,200 --> 01:26:59,740
Simple tweak to make.

1653
01:26:59,740 --> 01:27:01,480
If I was just running one SQL Server,

1654
01:27:01,480 --> 01:27:04,370
I probably wouldn't have messed with
that I would have just let it be.

1655
01:27:04,370 --> 01:27:07,179
But when I've got them coexisting,
I like to set limits.

1656
01:27:08,990 --> 01:27:09,720
All right.

1657
01:27:09,720 --> 01:27:10,600
So that's in place.

1658
01:27:10,600 --> 01:27:11,510
I can restart that one.

1659
01:27:13,280 --> 01:27:15,570
We'll let it restart and
then we'll be good to go.

1660
01:27:15,570 --> 01:27:16,900
All right.

1661
01:27:16,900 --> 01:27:18,830
So getting SQL installed, not a big deal.

1662
01:27:18,830 --> 01:27:19,510
All right?

1663
01:27:19,510 --> 01:27:21,120
Now that it's installed,
what do we do with it?

1664
01:27:21,120 --> 01:27:23,890
Well, it's kinda useless
the way that it is right now.

1665
01:27:23,890 --> 01:27:24,550
It's just sitting there.

1666
01:27:24,550 --> 01:27:25,920
It's got some empty databases on it.

1667
01:27:25,920 --> 01:27:27,410
It's not doing anything.

1668
01:27:27,410 --> 01:27:31,700
So our next step is going to be to
put some databases in there and

1669
01:27:31,700 --> 01:27:34,660
actually get it doing something for
our company.

1670
01:27:34,660 --> 01:27:37,260
So that's gonna come down the line.

1671
01:27:37,260 --> 01:27:40,850
Let's see, what else do we have?

1672
01:27:40,850 --> 01:27:42,780
That's really about it.

1673
01:27:42,780 --> 01:27:45,120
If I was upgrading from
another version of SQL,

1674
01:27:45,120 --> 01:27:49,690
if I was going an in place upgrade then
the old databases would show up right now.

1675
01:27:49,690 --> 01:27:53,458
If I was doing another type of migration,
though, where I've got separate servers.

1676
01:27:53,458 --> 01:27:57,418
This is the point where I would either
backup the databases on the old server and

1677
01:27:57,418 --> 01:28:00,778
restore them here on the new server or
detach the database files and

1678
01:28:00,778 --> 01:28:02,518
copy them over and reattach them or

1679
01:28:02,518 --> 01:28:05,800
whatever it is that I was gonna
do as part of that upgrade.

1680
01:28:05,800 --> 01:28:08,375
We'll see detaching, and
reattaching later on.

1681
01:28:08,375 --> 01:28:10,875
Its an easy way to move databases,
and do upgrades.

1682
01:28:10,875 --> 01:28:15,498
So we'll get a chance to see that, but
otherwise, we now have a SQL Server that's

1683
01:28:15,498 --> 01:28:18,320
up and running, and
its ready for us to work with.

1684
01:28:18,320 --> 01:28:18,820
All right.

1685
01:28:18,820 --> 01:28:22,360
Well, looking at the clock, that's about
all the time I've got for this episode.

1686
01:28:22,360 --> 01:28:26,650
So we'll start tackling databases, in
the second episode, and jump from there.

1687
01:28:26,650 --> 01:28:29,850
Great question there, in the chat room,
let me answer this one real quick,

1688
01:28:29,850 --> 01:28:30,653
before we wrap up.

1689
01:28:30,653 --> 01:28:32,820
Which is,
if you were running a web server.

1690
01:28:32,820 --> 01:28:33,403
Right?

1691
01:28:33,403 --> 01:28:37,606
So you got a web server, and if the
database server is right there on the same

1692
01:28:37,606 --> 01:28:39,695
system, are they going to contend?

1693
01:28:39,695 --> 01:28:40,820
Right?
And the answer is yes.

1694
01:28:40,820 --> 01:28:42,420
Yeah.
They're gonna fight for memory.

1695
01:28:42,420 --> 01:28:44,490
And so
you can put limits to protect from that.

1696
01:28:44,490 --> 01:28:45,210
The problem is,

1697
01:28:45,210 --> 01:28:49,872
the web server doesn't really, like IIS,
doesn't take limits very well.

1698
01:28:49,872 --> 01:28:53,400
So you're up to your
host OS to regulate that.

1699
01:28:53,400 --> 01:28:55,980
If you just let them go wild,
they compete for

1700
01:28:55,980 --> 01:28:59,170
the resources, on a first come,
first serve basis.

1701
01:28:59,170 --> 01:29:02,810
And in IIS,
it can spiral out of control sometimes.

1702
01:29:02,810 --> 01:29:07,320
If they both start to go for extra memory,
they'll get it, even if you run out of

1703
01:29:07,320 --> 01:29:10,740
physical memory, and what that means is,
you'll start paging.

1704
01:29:10,740 --> 01:29:14,600
Instead of using physical memory, it'll
start writing to the page file on the hard

1705
01:29:14,600 --> 01:29:18,340
drive, so now you're creating disc IO,
which is slower.

1706
01:29:18,340 --> 01:29:19,870
It's already slower than memory, right?

1707
01:29:19,870 --> 01:29:22,820
Because in RAM,
we measure speed in nanoseconds, but

1708
01:29:22,820 --> 01:29:24,380
on the hard drive,
we measure it in milliseconds.

1709
01:29:24,380 --> 01:29:26,540
So it's an order of magnitude different,
but

1710
01:29:26,540 --> 01:29:30,540
it's even more slow because, now our
memory is being read from the hard drive.

1711
01:29:30,540 --> 01:29:33,750
The same hard drive that our OS,
and SQL server is running from.

1712
01:29:33,750 --> 01:29:35,620
Now we get a lot of contention there.

1713
01:29:35,620 --> 01:29:37,890
So you don't want that to happen.

1714
01:29:37,890 --> 01:29:39,960
Implementing limits like these,
is how we prevent it.

1715
01:29:39,960 --> 01:29:40,530
Right?

1716
01:29:40,530 --> 01:29:42,390
But an even better thing to do?

1717
01:29:42,390 --> 01:29:46,800
If that web server, is a production
use web server, split it off,

1718
01:29:46,800 --> 01:29:50,430
split it separate, don't run your database
on the same server, as your web server.

1719
01:29:50,430 --> 01:29:52,820
Now you start to get better management,
and isolation.

1720
01:29:52,820 --> 01:29:55,658
So as your company grows,
as your user base grows,

1721
01:29:55,658 --> 01:30:00,153
your equipment needs to start to grow,
and you really do get complex kinda fast.

1722
01:30:00,153 --> 01:30:01,520
All right.
Great question Mike, thanks for that.

1723
01:30:03,150 --> 01:30:05,590
All right.
Well, let me remind you guys.

1724
01:30:05,590 --> 01:30:08,560
If you have questions,
like those, live during the show,

1725
01:30:08,560 --> 01:30:10,510
you can jump over to www.itpro.tv/live.

1726
01:30:10,510 --> 01:30:13,200
And you'll see the chat room
right beneath the video.

1727

Post your questions there.

1728

We love to answer them during the show,

1729
01:30:17,620 --> 01:30:19,220
If you have questions afterwards,

1730
01:30:19,220 --> 01:30:22,150
like if you're watching this recorded,
use our Q&A forums.

1731
01:30:22,150 --> 01:30:25,580
At the top of every page, is a link that
says Q&A, it'll take you into the forums,

1732
01:30:25,580 --> 01:30:26,980
you can post your questions there.

1733
01:30:26,980 --> 01:30:28,000
We monitor and answer.

1734
01:30:28,000 --> 01:30:31,030
We wanna make sure you guys
have answers in your mind, and

1735
01:30:31,030 --> 01:30:33,300
not questions,
when you go into that test booth.

1736
01:30:33,300 --> 01:30:37,110
So take advantage of that resource,
it is there for you.

1737
01:30:37,110 --> 01:30:39,118
All right.
Well I hope you guys enjoyed the show,

1738
01:30:39,118 --> 01:30:40,361
signing off for ITProTV.

1739
01:30:40,361 --> 01:30:43,653
I'm Don Pezet, and I'll see you next time.

episodes.description: In this episode Don demonstrates how to create databases in Microsoft SQL. He then discusses how important the underlying file system is in terms of SQL performance.
episodes.title: Manage and Configure Databases
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,680 --> 00:00:36,541
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening.

3
00:00:36,541 --> 00:00:38,820
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:38,820 --> 00:00:44,450
I'm your host, Don Pezet, back again with
another episode of Microsoft SQL Sever.

5
00:00:44,450 --> 00:00:48,720
In our last episode, we got a chance to
see how to get Microsoft SQL installed.

6
00:00:48,720 --> 00:00:51,820
We learned a bit about the product and
saw that process, but

7
00:00:51,820 --> 00:00:54,110
we didn't actually do anything with it.

8
00:00:54,110 --> 00:00:57,300
By the end of the episode, sure,
we'd created a SQL Server, but

9
00:00:57,300 --> 00:00:59,430
it really served no purpose.

10
00:00:59,430 --> 00:01:04,470
And that's how database servers are until
you start to put some databases on them,

11
00:01:04,470 --> 00:01:06,260
and that's what we're gonna do today.

12
00:01:06,260 --> 00:01:09,080
We're gonna take a look at how
we can create a database and

13
00:01:09,080 --> 00:01:10,960
how we can put it in action.

14
00:01:10,960 --> 00:01:13,930
So that is a lot of neat stuff to tackle.

15
00:01:13,930 --> 00:01:15,390
So that's where we're gonna go.

16
00:01:15,390 --> 00:01:18,790
Before I do that though, I do wanna talk
a little bit about how the databases work

17
00:01:18,790 --> 00:01:20,810
and what all is involved in them.

18
00:01:20,810 --> 00:01:23,660
When people think of Microsoft SQL, or

19
00:01:23,660 --> 00:01:26,760
just database servers in general,
oftentimes what they envision in

20
00:01:26,760 --> 00:01:30,060
their mind is something a little
different than what we actually have.

21
00:01:30,060 --> 00:01:32,590
A lot of people think of tables, right?

22
00:01:32,590 --> 00:01:34,970
Let me bring up my model diagrams here.

23
00:01:34,970 --> 00:01:37,680
So most people think of tables like this,
right?

24
00:01:37,680 --> 00:01:42,060
Here's a sample table where we've got
Employees, so we've got first name,

25
00:01:42,060 --> 00:01:45,200
last name, hire date,
pay rate, manager, and so on.

26
00:01:45,200 --> 00:01:48,760
These are our tables of information,
and in a database,

27
00:01:48,760 --> 00:01:50,800
tables are what you normally work with.

28
00:01:50,800 --> 00:01:55,210
But a database is not a single table,

29
00:01:55,210 --> 00:01:58,000
a database is actually
a collection of tables.

30
00:01:58,000 --> 00:02:00,440
You might only have one, but
you might have a thousand,

31
00:02:00,440 --> 00:02:01,840
you might have a million tables.

32
00:02:01,840 --> 00:02:05,040
It depends on how much data you're
managing and how you're working with it.

33
00:02:05,040 --> 00:02:08,150
We won't normally have a million,
that would be pretty excessive, but

34
00:02:08,150 --> 00:02:10,260
you could if you wanted.

35
00:02:10,260 --> 00:02:12,080
In the table is our data, and

36
00:02:12,080 --> 00:02:17,570
our data is comprised of values
stored inside of columns and rows.

37
00:02:17,570 --> 00:02:21,360
So, if you've worked with a spreadsheet
program like Microsoft Excel,

38
00:02:21,360 --> 00:02:25,030
or Google Docs, what do they call theirs?

39
00:02:25,030 --> 00:02:27,680
Sheets or something like that,
Apple Numbers, whatever.

40
00:02:27,680 --> 00:02:30,380
If you've worked with any of
those different products, well,

41
00:02:30,380 --> 00:02:31,330
that's basically a table.

42
00:02:31,330 --> 00:02:33,300
And it's basically a database table.

43
00:02:33,300 --> 00:02:37,060
But what you're missing
are the relationships between

44
00:02:37,060 --> 00:02:41,450
that table in your spreadsheet software
and another table somewhere else.

45
00:02:41,450 --> 00:02:46,200
In a database we can have several
tables that are all related together.

46
00:02:46,200 --> 00:02:48,900
That's why they call these
a relational database.

47
00:02:48,900 --> 00:02:53,660
I might have an ID number here that
contains data that references back

48
00:02:53,660 --> 00:02:56,960
to other tables, or
even data within this table itself.

49
00:02:56,960 --> 00:02:59,760
See how I've got Andrew Aimes here.

50
00:02:59,760 --> 00:03:04,030
Andrew Aimes is an employee, he's employee
number three, and he has a manager.

51
00:03:04,030 --> 00:03:06,010
The manager's ID is number one.

52
00:03:06,010 --> 00:03:10,220
Well that number one, that's not a person,
we don't have an employee named one.

53
00:03:10,220 --> 00:03:11,520
It's a reference.

54
00:03:11,520 --> 00:03:13,620
It references back to this ID.

55
00:03:13,620 --> 00:03:15,980
Whoever employee ID number one is,
in this case,

56
00:03:15,980 --> 00:03:18,820
John Smith, that's Andrew's boss, right?

57
00:03:18,820 --> 00:03:19,970
That's a relationship.

58
00:03:19,970 --> 00:03:24,030
And that's a very simple example of one
happening right here inside of one table.

59
00:03:24,030 --> 00:03:25,440
But more often than not,

60
00:03:25,440 --> 00:03:28,492
those relationships exist
between multiple tables.

61
00:03:28,492 --> 00:03:33,460
I might have one table that lists all
the products that my company sells.

62
00:03:33,460 --> 00:03:37,820
I may have another table that lists all
the orders that customers have placed.

63
00:03:37,820 --> 00:03:41,280
Well in the orders, I have to
identify what products people bought.

64
00:03:41,280 --> 00:03:44,020
And so we'll normally have
a reference on that order

65
00:03:44,020 --> 00:03:46,600
that points back to a products
table somewhere else.

66
00:03:46,600 --> 00:03:48,250
So when we create a database,

67
00:03:48,250 --> 00:03:52,370
that database is really just
a storage location for these tables.

68
00:03:52,370 --> 00:03:57,040
So the tables are what we work with, but
the databases are where they get stored.

69
00:03:57,040 --> 00:04:01,420
And the reason that I bring that up here
is when we go to build a new database,

70
00:04:01,420 --> 00:04:04,570
the first thing that needs to
be in our mind is storage.

71
00:04:04,570 --> 00:04:09,180
We're storing data, and where we store
it is gonna influence a lot of things,

72
00:04:09,180 --> 00:04:11,350
the most important of
which being performance.

73
00:04:11,350 --> 00:04:13,180
If you want your database to run nice and

74
00:04:13,180 --> 00:04:15,809
fast, there's things you've got to
think about before you create it.

75
00:04:17,280 --> 00:04:20,020
The first thing we need to deal with
when it comes to creating storage

76
00:04:20,020 --> 00:04:23,220
is understanding that
the database is actually made up

77
00:04:23,220 --> 00:04:24,980
of several different components.

78
00:04:24,980 --> 00:04:29,240
But the two main components that we need
to remember are the database itself and

79
00:04:29,240 --> 00:04:30,270
the transaction logs.

80
00:04:30,270 --> 00:04:33,850
All right,
now what the heck is a transaction log?

81
00:04:33,850 --> 00:04:35,760
Transaction logs are a great technology.

82
00:04:35,760 --> 00:04:39,320
Something that has been around for
a long, long time.

83
00:04:40,700 --> 00:04:45,200
When you deal with databases,
if you write data to it, there is a chance

84
00:04:45,200 --> 00:04:48,310
that you could get database corruption,
and the corruption would be bad, right?

85
00:04:48,310 --> 00:04:51,780
If it's a mission critical database,
you want your data to be safe, and so

86
00:04:51,780 --> 00:04:53,570
you want to prevent errors.

87
00:04:53,570 --> 00:04:57,740
Well in the old days, or
even today with like Microsoft Excel,

88
00:04:57,740 --> 00:05:01,020
when you're writing to that spreadsheet,
what are you writing to?

89
00:05:01,020 --> 00:05:02,960
You're writing to the spreadsheet itself.

90
00:05:02,960 --> 00:05:05,050
And in the old days of
databases that's what you did.

91
00:05:05,050 --> 00:05:06,820
You wrote it to the database itself.

92
00:05:06,820 --> 00:05:11,000
So if a client wanted to write
some data into a database,

93
00:05:11,000 --> 00:05:15,180
they would connect up and send their
data right into that database directly.

94
00:05:16,240 --> 00:05:22,250
Well, what would happen if there was a
power failure halfway through that write,

95
00:05:22,250 --> 00:05:25,810
or our network connection was
lost halfway through that write?

96
00:05:25,810 --> 00:05:29,490
Well, you've written half
your data to the database.

97
00:05:29,490 --> 00:05:31,520
The rest of it is lost.

98
00:05:31,520 --> 00:05:34,040
So now we've got a partial
write on the database,

99
00:05:34,040 --> 00:05:35,970
which is basically data corruption.

100
00:05:35,970 --> 00:05:40,040
If we were overriding something else,
we've only overridden a portion of it, and

101
00:05:40,040 --> 00:05:41,970
now our data is broken.

102
00:05:41,970 --> 00:05:44,130
So we end up with database corruption.

103
00:05:44,130 --> 00:05:47,090
And when you're just dealing with a simple
spreadsheet, it's not a big deal.

104
00:05:47,090 --> 00:05:49,780
You've probably got a backup,
you can just pull it back up.

105
00:05:49,780 --> 00:05:53,110
But when you're dealing with
a database that might have thousands or

106
00:05:53,110 --> 00:05:56,820
hundreds of thousands of users in it
that are all relying upon that data,

107
00:05:56,820 --> 00:06:00,330
when you get that data corruption that'll
be the end of your day right there.

108
00:06:00,330 --> 00:06:01,300
That's a big deal.

109
00:06:02,320 --> 00:06:08,440
So with databases, we never allow people
to write directly to the database.

110
00:06:08,440 --> 00:06:09,760
There are ways to do it.

111
00:06:09,760 --> 00:06:11,440
There's special exceptions.

112
00:06:11,440 --> 00:06:15,900
But the general rule is no one is allowed
to write directly to the database.

113
00:06:15,900 --> 00:06:19,520
Instead, if somebody wants
to write to the database,

114
00:06:19,520 --> 00:06:23,130
they write to the transaction
logs instead.

115
00:06:23,130 --> 00:06:27,050
They bypass the database, and
write to the transaction log.

116
00:06:28,850 --> 00:06:32,840
By doing this,
we're writing to a separate location.

117
00:06:32,840 --> 00:06:38,100
And when our change is 100%
written into that transaction log,

118
00:06:38,100 --> 00:06:43,020
so when our change is fully written in
there and our data is put in place,

119
00:06:43,020 --> 00:06:46,870
then SQL Server will come back behind and

120
00:06:46,870 --> 00:06:51,940
take that data, and
write it over into our database.

121
00:06:51,940 --> 00:06:56,210
So the data gets put into the database,
just not directly.

122
00:06:56,210 --> 00:07:00,670
We can't go and write directly into it,
we go round about.

123
00:07:00,670 --> 00:07:04,420
We write to the transaction log when it's

00:33:04,180 --> 00:33:09,270

the next time I'll grow to 1.1 gig,

01:06:40,710 --> 01:06:45,560

01:06:45,560 --> 01:06:50,170

01:06:50,170 --> 01:06:51,780
So it's going to grow
based on that percentage.

1265
01:06:53,220 --> 01:06:55,495
You can also specify a maximum.

1266
01:06:55,495 --> 01:06:57,625
If you don't specify a maximum,

1267
01:06:57,625 --> 01:07:02,115
the database can grow to fill
the entire hard drive, all right.

01:07:02,115 --> 01:07:03,475
That may or not be a problem.

01:07:03,475 --> 01:07:05,325

drive space utilization,

01:07:05,325 --> 01:07:08,365

01:07:10,755 --> 01:07:14,215

01:07:14,215 --> 01:07:16,180

1277
01:07:27,840 --> 01:07:30,150

1278
01:07:30,150 --> 01:07:33,510

1279
01:07:33,510 --> 01:07:36,560
If your database is on your C drive,

1280
01:07:37,660 --> 01:07:39,920
If your database is on
a dedicated drive like mine,

1281
01:07:39,920 --> 01:07:43,740

1282
01:07:43,740 --> 01:07:46,120

one doesn't take up all the space.

1283
01:07:46,120 --> 01:07:47,830
You might set a maximum there.

1284
01:07:47,830 --> 01:07:53,510
So, maybe I'll limit
mine to ten gigs in size.

1285
01:07:53,510 --> 01:07:57,720
And I'm going to say that every time it
grows, it's going to grow by one gig.

1286
01:07:59,040 --> 01:08:01,950
So my initial size is one gig.

1287
01:08:01,950 --> 01:08:04,940
Every time it grows,
it'll grow by one gig.

1288
01:08:04,940 --> 01:08:08,050
And that means it's

1289
01:08:08,050 --> 01:08:10,650
I've got it set with

1290
01:08:10,650 --> 01:08:12,900
I'll never get more than

1291
01:08:12,900 --> 01:08:15,980
As each one hits, it'll grow by
a gig until it gets to ten gigs, and

1292
01:08:15,980 --> 01:08:16,950

1293
01:08:16,950 --> 01:08:20,410
When it hits ten gigs, the database

1294
01:08:20,410 --> 01:08:22,430
I won't be able to write
data to it anymore.

1295
01:08:22,430 --> 01:08:23,230
It's full.

1296
01:08:23,230 --> 01:08:25,810
I'll still be able to read data,
but I don't be able to write to it.

1297
01:08:27,170 --> 01:08:29,680
You can do the same thing

1298
01:08:29,680 --> 01:08:32,256
Remember every time you make
a change to the database,

1299
01:08:32,256 --> 01:08:36,680

1300
01:08:36,680 --> 01:08:39,740
The only difference here is when
you right data to the database,

1301
01:08:39,740 --> 01:08:41,340

1302
01:08:41,340 --> 01:08:43,710
When you write data to
the transaction logs,

1303
01:08:43,710 --> 01:08:45,910

1304
01:08:45,910 --> 01:08:47,370

1305
01:08:47,370 --> 01:08:51,120

the transaction log and empty it out.

1306
01:08:51,120 --> 01:08:55,000
So your transaction logs are getting empty
every time you run a backup versus your

1307
01:08:55,000 --> 01:08:57,560

gonna have it always.

1308
01:08:57,560 --> 01:09:01,780
So your transaction logs are normally
smaller based on the amount of changes.

1309
01:09:01,780 --> 01:09:05,220
If you have a read only database,
your transaction logs will be empty.

1310
01:09:05,220 --> 01:09:07,080
They might be very small.

1311
01:09:07,080 --> 01:09:10,250
But if you've got a database
that's under frequent change,

1312
01:09:10,250 --> 01:09:13,520

1313
01:09:13,520 --> 01:09:17,650

1314
01:09:17,650 --> 01:09:20,960

01:09:27,770 --> 01:09:30,260

01:09:30,260 --> 01:09:31,340

01:09:31,340 --> 01:09:35,820

1319
01:09:37,040 --> 01:09:40,990
But that means that if I have more
than a gig of changes between backups,

1320
01:09:40,990 --> 01:09:44,660
my database will go read only,

1321
01:09:44,660 --> 01:09:47,870
So, having transaction logs on their own
hard drive ensures that they can grow just

1322
01:09:47,870 --> 01:09:51,300

01:10:34,660 --> 01:10:37,910

You just get the data up

You lose data that way, but

01:15:11,510 --> 01:15:15,960

If you've got a column where the year

01:15:20,530 --> 01:15:26,850

I don't know, right?

01:15:28,800 --> 01:15:31,200
That was really the whole

01:15:34,460 --> 01:15:36,560

01:15:40,097 --> 01:15:42,280

01:15:42,280 --> 01:15:47,566
It basically says, all right,

01:15:47,566 --> 01:15:55,565

01:15:55,565 --> 01:15:58,742

01:16:06,280 --> 01:16:13,010
This is the two-digit year cutoff that

the query analyzer and run it.

1930
01:41:20,520 --> 01:41:21,180
Off we go.

1931
01:41:21,180 --> 01:41:23,480
So really easy to reuse this stuff.

1932
01:41:25,550 --> 01:41:27,428
And if you have developers in house,

1933
01:41:27,428 --> 01:41:32,435
a lot of times what they'll do is they'll
create a code repository, and you can

1934
01:41:32,435 --> 01:41:37,585
actually link your SQL Management Studio
to it, so you can get access to snippets.

1935
01:41:37,585 --> 01:41:40,467
Right, all the resources they share, so
as people write these, they share them and

1936
01:41:40,467 --> 01:41:42,475
it becomes available in your environment.

1937
01:41:42,475 --> 01:41:44,515
If it's just you,
you probably don't need all that.

1938
01:41:44,515 --> 01:41:47,189
But if there's other people out there,
it is handy.

1939
01:41:50,420 --> 01:41:53,430
So that's probably a good spot for
us to wrap today.

1940
01:41:53,430 --> 01:41:56,230
There is more that I wanna
talk about on the databases.

1941
01:41:56,230 --> 01:42:00,600
For example, we created a database and
we never actually put anything in it.

1942
01:42:00,600 --> 01:42:03,960
And once the data gets in there, there's
all sorts of stuff we can do to rearrange

1943
01:42:03,960 --> 01:42:07,230
where it's stored on our hard drives,
and how we do backups, and so on.

1944
01:42:07,230 --> 01:42:10,710
So, I know we mentioned file groups,
but I never actually got into that too.

1945
01:42:10,710 --> 01:42:13,150
So we'll tackle file groups
in the next episode.

1946
01:42:13,150 --> 01:42:17,210
We'll take a look at table partitioning
and a couple other really cool things, so

1947
01:42:17,210 --> 01:42:19,980
definitely stay tuned for that.

1948
01:42:19,980 --> 01:42:23,300
But for this episode,
let's go ahead and wrap it up here.

1949
01:42:23,300 --> 01:42:24,220
Let me remind you guys,

1950

if you have questions on anything

All right, well I hope you guys enjoyed

episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,427 --> 00:00:36,445
Good morning, good afternoon and
good evening.

3
00:00:36,445 --> 00:00:39,151
And welcome back for
another episode of ITProTV,

4
00:00:39,151 --> 00:00:43,609
I'm your host Don Pezet back again with
another episode of Microsoft SQL Server.

5
00:00:43,609 --> 00:00:48,158
We're gonna dive right back in, jumping in
after the content we covered in the last

6
00:00:48,158 --> 00:00:50,505
episode, which was creating databases.

7
00:00:50,505 --> 00:00:54,820
So in the last episode, we got a chance
to see how to create the database and

8
00:00:54,820 --> 00:00:59,014
I talked about the files and where we
store them and ways to optimize it.

9
00:00:59,014 --> 00:01:01,880
We got a chance to see RAID arrays and
all that good stuff,

10
00:01:01,880 --> 00:01:03,264
now I want to build on that.

11
00:01:03,264 --> 00:01:05,979
Now at the end of the last episode,
you could have stopped and

12
00:01:05,979 --> 00:01:07,908
you've got a fully functional database.

13
00:01:07,908 --> 00:01:11,955
You're ready to start throwing data
in there, just chucking it all in and

14
00:01:11,955 --> 00:01:12,814
giving it a go.

15
00:01:12,814 --> 00:01:17,546
But there are a few other optimizations
we might wanna make before we do that and

16
00:01:17,546 --> 00:01:22,208
it's important that we know what we're
doing ahead of time, because once we

17
00:01:22,208 --> 00:01:27,178
start throwing our data into the database,
it becomes very difficult to move it.

18
00:01:27,178 --> 00:01:31,720
So a well designed, well planned
database infrastructure starts

19
00:01:31,720 --> 00:01:34,652
before there's any data in the database.

20
00:01:34,652 --> 00:01:38,946
I've not created a single
table in my database just yet.

21
00:01:38,946 --> 00:01:41,593
Tables, that's where our
actual data is gonna go.

22
00:01:41,593 --> 00:01:44,971
I think I brought an example up in the
last show, but let me bring it up again.

23
00:01:44,971 --> 00:01:47,584
So here's an example of a table.

24
00:01:47,584 --> 00:01:50,209
This is what our end users want and
what our developers want.

25
00:01:50,209 --> 00:01:53,235
They want a place to be able to
store data and retrieve it, so

26
00:01:53,235 --> 00:01:56,826
they can do a query to say,
return the data for employee number three.

27
00:01:56,826 --> 00:02:01,160
And it'll reach in the first name,
the last name and so on for Andrew Aimes,

28
00:02:01,160 --> 00:02:06,206
that's what they want, but we've created a
database to this point that has no tables.

29
00:02:06,206 --> 00:02:10,669
So we haven't even gotten there, but
the reason is we wanna make sure we've

30
00:02:10,669 --> 00:02:13,764
designed everything properly
from the beginning.

31
00:02:13,764 --> 00:02:18,731
If we don't, if we have a poorly designed
database or if we have a database that was

32
00:02:18,731 --> 00:02:22,412
fine when our company was small,
but now our company is big.

33
00:02:22,412 --> 00:02:24,258
We need to change it.

34
00:02:24,258 --> 00:02:28,772
And unfortunately, there's not a good
way to move tables between files or

35
00:02:28,772 --> 00:02:31,864
move tables between
underlying infrastructure.

36
00:02:31,864 --> 00:02:37,320
So what you end up having to do is to wipe
out the table and recreate the table.

37
00:02:37,320 --> 00:02:39,978
Now it sounds bad,
it's really not that bad.

38
00:02:39,978 --> 00:02:43,507
Any object inside of SQL,
you can right-click on it and

39
00:02:43,507 --> 00:02:45,702
choose Script as drop and create.

40
00:02:45,702 --> 00:02:48,724
And what it will, here let me show you,
cuz you know I rattle these things off and

41
00:02:48,724 --> 00:02:50,183
sometimes it's a little confusing.

42
00:02:50,183 --> 00:02:55,384
So if we've made a database, for example,
the whole database and it's just perfect.

43
00:02:55,384 --> 00:02:57,404
It's got everything that we wanted.

44
00:02:57,404 --> 00:03:04,300
Well, you can right-click on it and
choose Script Database as Drop and Create.

45
00:03:04,300 --> 00:03:07,425
When you do that,
it's gonna create a script for

46
00:03:07,425 --> 00:03:11,022
you that will delete the database and
then recreate it.

47
00:03:11,022 --> 00:03:13,740
Recreate it, so
that you can modify it however you need.

48
00:03:13,740 --> 00:03:17,105
So if I do that,
I'll choose Drop and Create to.

49
00:03:17,105 --> 00:03:17,837
Here it is.

50
00:03:17,837 --> 00:03:18,998
It's kinda laying this out for me.

51
00:03:18,998 --> 00:03:22,585
You'll see right here,
Drop Database Products.

52
00:03:22,585 --> 00:03:25,370
That's gonna delete
that products database.

53
00:03:25,370 --> 00:03:29,336
And then right after it,
it creates the product's database and

54
00:03:29,336 --> 00:03:33,680
it applies all the settings and
everything just the way that we had it.

55
00:03:33,680 --> 00:03:37,360
So you might look at the script and
say, well, what's the point in this?

56
00:03:37,360 --> 00:03:40,855
Why would I wanna wipe the data base
out and then just recreate it again?

57
00:03:40,855 --> 00:03:42,353
What does that achieve?

58
00:03:42,353 --> 00:03:44,036
Well, it doesn't achieve anything.

59
00:03:44,036 --> 00:03:45,080
If I were to run this,

60
00:03:45,080 --> 00:03:48,099
I would be in the exact same
position that I was before I ran it.

61
00:03:48,099 --> 00:03:50,654
But now, we can go in and modify it.

62
00:03:50,654 --> 00:03:54,996
We can go in and put changes in here to
modify the way that we want it to build.

63
00:03:54,996 --> 00:03:56,656
We can change the file name.

64
00:03:56,656 --> 00:04:00,277
Maybe I chose a different file
name before and I really hate it.

65
00:04:00,277 --> 00:04:01,415
And so, I wanna change the file name.

66
00:04:01,415 --> 00:04:02,414
Well, I could do it here.

67
00:04:02,414 --> 00:04:04,840
I could change that file name or
the location.

68
00:04:04,840 --> 00:04:07,953
I could turn encryption off as
opposed to having encryption on,

69
00:04:07,953 --> 00:04:10,446
whatever it is that we
wanted we could then modify.

70
00:04:10,446 --> 00:04:14,258
A lot of these you could change
while the database is in place,

71
00:04:14,258 --> 00:04:18,968
there are some things you can't and
one of those is where a table is located.

72
00:04:18,968 --> 00:04:23,702
When we create a table, a table is stored
in the database in a particular place and

73
00:04:23,702 --> 00:04:25,598
there's no good way to move it.

74
00:04:25,598 --> 00:04:29,823
So we can use a Drop and Create script,
like this to drop the table and

75
00:04:29,823 --> 00:04:33,470
then recreate it and
specify a different location for it.

76
00:04:33,470 --> 00:04:36,057
Now when I talk about locations,
what do I mean?

77
00:04:36,057 --> 00:04:39,720
Well, remember yesterday's example,
where I took our server and

78
00:04:39,720 --> 00:04:43,191
was talking about separating out
the components of our system,

79
00:04:43,191 --> 00:04:46,532
where we might have our operating
system on one set of drives,

80
00:04:46,532 --> 00:04:51,246
our database on another set of drives, our
transaction logs on another set of drives.

81
00:04:51,246 --> 00:04:58,049
And in fact, on a highly tuned SQL Server
will actually have one more entry in here.

82
00:04:58,049 --> 00:05:03,366
Let me just update this a little bit
to reflect that one other entry.

83
00:05:03,366 --> 00:05:04,806
Well, shoot.

84
00:05:04,806 --> 00:05:08,624
[LAUGH] This should not
be as hard as it is.

85
00:05:08,624 --> 00:05:09,485
There we go.

86
00:05:09,485 --> 00:05:11,550
So there'll be one other entry,

87
00:05:11,550 --> 00:05:14,884
which'll be your page file
in a highly tuned server.

88
00:05:14,884 --> 00:05:17,471
Hopefully, you aren't using the page file.

89
00:05:17,471 --> 00:05:21,687
That you should have enough RAM in your
system that you don't need it, but

90
00:05:21,687 --> 00:05:24,203
it's pretty common to
move your swap file or

91
00:05:24,203 --> 00:05:27,320
your page file to a separate
set of disks also.

92
00:05:27,320 --> 00:05:31,090
So in a highly optimized server, you might
have a configuration that's like this.

93
00:05:32,210 --> 00:05:36,392
Well, if I create my database and
I put it right here on the RAID 5 array,

94
00:05:36,392 --> 00:05:37,845
I get certain benefits.

95
00:05:37,845 --> 00:05:40,210
I can write a little bit faster or
not much,

96
00:05:40,210 --> 00:05:42,652
we talked about RAID 5
on the last episode.

97
00:05:42,652 --> 00:05:44,231
So we get a little bit
of a performance boost.

98
00:05:44,231 --> 00:05:47,098
And when I read, I get a little
bit of a performance boost, but

99
00:05:47,098 --> 00:05:48,211
I also get redundancy.

100
00:05:48,211 --> 00:05:51,280
That's my extra benefit there.

101
00:05:51,280 --> 00:05:54,269
And then all these mirrors
while I'm getting redundancy,

102
00:05:54,269 --> 00:05:55,891
but no real performance boost.

103
00:05:55,891 --> 00:06:01,471
Now my data is right there on
that RAID 5 array, right here.

104
00:06:01,471 --> 00:06:06,379
Well, inside of my database,
I may have more than one table.

105
00:06:06,379 --> 00:06:10,620
And if I have more than one table,
if those tables are being used

106
00:06:10,620 --> 00:06:15,038
simultaneously, the tables
are competing against each other.

107
00:06:15,038 --> 00:06:16,780
Now how do we fix that?

108
00:06:16,780 --> 00:06:20,798
If I have competing disk I/O
between two different tables,

109
00:06:20,798 --> 00:06:25,365
maybe I've got a database from my
company and in there is one table for

110
00:06:25,365 --> 00:06:28,379
my products and
another table for my orders.

111
00:06:28,379 --> 00:06:32,138
So every time somebody is searching my
inventory, like you go to amazon.com and

112
00:06:32,138 --> 00:06:35,252
you search for products,
they're querying the products table.

113
00:06:35,252 --> 00:06:39,627
But every time somebody places an order,
they're writing to the orders table.

114
00:06:39,627 --> 00:06:40,960
Now I've got a conflict,

115
00:06:40,960 --> 00:06:43,877
I've got two different types
of access at the same time.

116
00:06:43,877 --> 00:06:47,094
Well, if those tables are stored
in the same database and

117
00:06:47,094 --> 00:06:51,330
the database is stored on these drives,
the tables will have contention.

118
00:06:51,330 --> 00:06:55,915
That's just how it is, but
we can take our database and

119
00:06:55,915 --> 00:06:58,715
break it up into multiple files.

120
00:06:58,715 --> 00:07:00,981
And if we break into multiple files,

121
00:07:00,981 --> 00:07:05,669
we can then put the tables in the
different files to remove that contention.

122
00:07:05,669 --> 00:07:10,133
So instead of having my database
just on one RAID 5 array and

123
00:07:10,133 --> 00:07:15,223
that's it, what I might actually
do is extend this even further and

124
00:07:15,223 --> 00:07:20,436
break my database up, so that it
spreads across more than one array.

125
00:07:20,436 --> 00:07:24,116
So some of my database tables
are one side and some on the other.

126
00:07:24,116 --> 00:07:27,525
Now, it's still just one database.

127
00:07:27,525 --> 00:07:29,521
It's not two databases, we could do that.

128
00:07:29,521 --> 00:07:31,704
We could create two databases.

129
00:07:31,704 --> 00:07:34,862
One database on one RAID 5 array,
another database on the other.

130
00:07:34,862 --> 00:07:39,949
The problem is sharing information between
databases becomes really difficult,

131
00:07:39,949 --> 00:07:44,606
you lose things like optimized index
lookups that we'll talk about later.

132
00:07:44,606 --> 00:07:48,074
You also lose things like primary
foreign key relationships, which again,

133
00:07:48,074 --> 00:07:49,472
we'll talk about that later.

134
00:07:49,472 --> 00:07:52,422
So you lose a lot when you
do separate databases.

135
00:07:52,422 --> 00:07:56,407
So it would be nice,
if we could take one database and

136
00:07:56,407 --> 00:07:59,132
split it up across multiple files.

137
00:07:59,132 --> 00:08:02,707
When we do that, when we create a table,

138
00:08:02,707 --> 00:08:07,190
we can specify what file
the table resides in.

139
00:08:07,190 --> 00:08:11,360
So maybe one table resides in
the database file on this array, and

140
00:08:11,360 --> 00:08:16,870
the other table, like my orders table,
resides in the file in this other array.

141
00:08:16,870 --> 00:08:20,450
Now I've eliminated discontention
between those two tables.

142
00:08:20,450 --> 00:08:23,900
That are in the same database, but
now they have that separate discontention.

143
00:08:24,910 --> 00:08:25,950
Let me show you how that's done.

144
00:08:25,950 --> 00:08:27,440
It's actually pretty easy.

145
00:08:27,440 --> 00:08:32,090
When we created this database, so
I'll take my products database here, and

146
00:08:32,090 --> 00:08:36,880
I'm just gonna pull up its properties,
when we created it,

147
00:08:36,880 --> 00:08:39,350
it asked us what files we wanted to make.

148
00:08:39,350 --> 00:08:41,270
And it made two files for us.

149
00:08:41,270 --> 00:08:44,320
I didn't make these right,
just when I typed in the database name,

150
00:08:44,320 --> 00:08:48,420
it automatically made these two files,
one was the database file the MDF,

151
00:08:48,420 --> 00:08:52,340
and the other one was
the transaction log file, the LDF.

152
00:08:52,340 --> 00:08:54,370
All right.
So it made those and

153
00:08:54,370 --> 00:08:55,940
it put them into a folder.

154
00:08:55,940 --> 00:08:59,500
Well, I could add more files, and

155
00:08:59,500 --> 00:09:02,940
you can do it when you're creating
the database,or you can do it afterwards.

156
00:09:02,940 --> 00:09:05,500
So I might come in here and
rename some of these.

157
00:09:05,500 --> 00:09:07,610
Right?
So I might want to do separate files,

158
00:09:07,610 --> 00:09:12,810
specifically for my orders and
my products table, okay?

159
00:09:12,810 --> 00:09:13,980
So I'm gonna take this.

160
00:09:13,980 --> 00:09:21,010
I've got my products file here, which is
C:/Program Files/Microsoft SQL Server.

161
00:09:21,010 --> 00:09:22,070
Actually you know what?

162
00:09:22,070 --> 00:09:23,270
Let's do an all new one here.

163
00:09:23,270 --> 00:09:25,470
Let's just cancel that.

164
00:09:25,470 --> 00:09:30,780
I'm gonna take this one, and
we'll do a, we'll do a new database.

165
00:09:30,780 --> 00:09:32,880
This will be like for
our inventory management, right, so

166
00:09:32,880 --> 00:09:35,282
I'm going to call this
my inventory database.

167
00:09:35,282 --> 00:09:37,810
All right, so here's the files
that it's going to make, and

168
00:09:37,810 --> 00:09:41,260
the reason that I want to do a new one,
is I want to do smaller pads than this.

169
00:09:41,260 --> 00:09:42,800
These are kind of long paths.

170
00:09:42,800 --> 00:09:47,290
So, I'm going to put this one on
my database folder on the E drive.

171
00:09:47,290 --> 00:09:50,830
And this other one,
on my transaction log folder over here.

172
00:09:52,300 --> 00:09:53,510
All right, so there we go.

173
00:09:53,510 --> 00:09:56,370
So now I've got those set up,
and I'll get that created.

174
00:09:56,370 --> 00:10:01,040
Now I'm going to take that inventory
database, and I'll pull up its properties,

175
00:10:01,040 --> 00:10:04,600
and I'll go under its files, and so
there's the two files that we just made,

176
00:10:04,600 --> 00:10:07,100
and their paths,
all fits on the screen now.

177
00:10:07,100 --> 00:10:07,930
Right.

178
00:10:07,930 --> 00:10:11,400
What I can do, is now I can start
to create additional files, and

179
00:10:11,400 --> 00:10:12,830
store them somewhere else.

180
00:10:12,830 --> 00:10:17,110
Now, I could create additional files and
store them on the same hard drive, but

181
00:10:17,110 --> 00:10:20,050
if I do that, I don't really
get any performance benefit.

182
00:10:20,050 --> 00:10:20,920
All right.

183
00:10:20,920 --> 00:10:24,540
What I do get is backup and restore
benefits, I'll talk about those later.

184
00:10:24,540 --> 00:10:26,850
But normally we're not gonna
put them on the same disk,

185
00:10:26,850 --> 00:10:28,840
we're gonna put them somewhere else.

186
00:10:28,840 --> 00:10:31,080
So I'll come in and add some more files,

187
00:10:31,080 --> 00:10:36,100
I'm gonna add a file
called inventory_ tbl,

188
00:10:36,100 --> 00:10:39,310
so I know this is gonna be
where I store one of my tables.

189
00:10:39,310 --> 00:10:42,150
And you can call these whatever you want,
this is my own naming col nvention,

190
00:10:42,150 --> 00:10:47,942
I usually put tbl so I can remember why
