Well, I hope you guys enjoyed the show.

1326
01:10:28,960 --> 01:10:33,320
Signing off for IT Pro TV,
I'm Don Pezet and I'll see you next time.

1327
01:10:33,320 --> 01:10:43,320
[MUSIC]

1328
01:10:52,240 --> 01:10:55,630
Time for a special after
the credits section of ITProTV.

1329
01:10:55,630 --> 01:11:00,390
At the very end of that episode,
I was creating a partition table and

1330
01:11:00,390 --> 01:11:02,590
when I actually went to run it,
it generated an error.

1331
01:11:02,590 --> 01:11:05,500
So, it didn't truly create the table.

1332
01:11:05,500 --> 01:11:08,043
Now I kind of passed over it
at the end of the episode, but

1333
01:11:08,043 --> 01:11:10,930
I know some of you guys are probably
curious why that happened.

1334
01:11:10,930 --> 01:11:13,395
Well, the reason has
to do with indexes and

1335
01:11:13,395 --> 01:11:16,560
we haven't covered indexes
at this point in the show.

1336
01:11:16,560 --> 01:11:19,890
So I didn't want to dive into the index
side of things in the show and

1337
01:11:19,890 --> 01:11:23,540
blow people's minds when they just learned
about partition tables in the first place.

1338
01:11:23,540 --> 01:11:27,060
So that's why I didn't resolve
that issue during the show.

1339
01:11:27,060 --> 01:11:29,790
But for those of you that are really
curious, let me show you how.

1340
01:11:29,790 --> 01:11:32,720
Now, if you haven't watched
our index episode yet,

1341
01:11:32,720 --> 01:11:34,010
you should probably go and watch that.

1342
01:11:34,010 --> 01:11:36,430
You need to make sure you
understand what indexes are.

1343
01:11:36,430 --> 01:11:40,381
But one thing I mentioned in the show
was that when we do a partition table,

1344
01:11:40,381 --> 01:11:43,123
the partitioning scheme
needs to be stored in RAM so

1345
01:11:43,123 --> 01:11:47,010
that the server knows where to copy
data to when it's being added.

1346
01:11:47,010 --> 01:11:49,690
And that's what it's really complaining
about down here, is it's saying I'm

1347
01:11:49,690 --> 01:11:54,140
trying to create this table and
I've got a primary key right here.

1348
01:11:54,140 --> 01:11:57,344
Your primary keys automatically
have an index created on them and

1349
01:11:57,344 --> 01:11:58,401
it's stored in RAM.

1350
01:11:58,401 --> 01:12:01,140
But that's not what I'm partitioning on,

1351
01:12:01,140 --> 01:12:05,146
I'm partitioning on store number,
which is not a primary key.

1352
01:12:05,146 --> 01:12:08,309
In the Microsoft example I brought up,
they were partitioning on a primary key,

1353
01:12:08,309 --> 01:12:09,859
so they didn't have to worry about it.

1354
01:12:09,859 --> 01:12:14,450
But in real life land, you almost
never partition off of a primary key.

1355
01:12:14,450 --> 01:12:16,970
Primary keys are unique, Right?

1356
01:12:16,970 --> 01:12:19,990
We need to partition based on dates or
store numbers.

1357
01:12:19,990 --> 01:12:21,500
Things that are not unique.

1358
01:12:21,500 --> 01:12:24,960
So the example that Microsoft gives on
their site is just not very realistic.

1359
01:12:24,960 --> 01:12:26,420
But the way that we fix it,

1360
01:12:26,420 --> 01:12:31,570
is by creating an index that
covers not only our primary key.

1361
01:12:31,570 --> 01:12:34,530
But also the item that we're
going to be partitioning on.

1362
01:12:34,530 --> 01:12:38,410
That will force the partitioned
item to remain in RAM and

1363
01:12:38,410 --> 01:12:40,510
make it where the server
knows where to send data.

1364
01:12:40,510 --> 01:12:41,910
That's what's missing here.

1365
01:12:41,910 --> 01:12:43,970
That's why this error was generated.

1366
01:12:43,970 --> 01:12:48,500
Because I don't have an index
that covers the store column.

1367
01:12:48,500 --> 01:12:52,050
So if I want to fix that,
when I created the table.

1368
01:12:52,050 --> 01:12:54,120
So here's the table definition.

1369
01:12:54,120 --> 01:12:57,230
We could flag ID as a primary key or not.

1370
01:12:57,230 --> 01:13:00,920
Usually, we don't do it right here but
instead assign a constraint.

1371
01:13:00,920 --> 01:13:01,980
And so see what I'm doing here,

1372
01:13:01,980 --> 01:13:07,570
I'm creating a constraint
that's saying orders ID store.

1373
01:13:07,570 --> 01:13:13,070
I'm creating a constraint that covers both
the ID number that I do want to be unique.

1374
01:13:13,070 --> 01:13:16,480
And the store number,
which is what I'm partitioning on.

1375
01:13:16,480 --> 01:13:18,870
That'll force both of them to go into RAM.

1376
01:13:18,870 --> 01:13:24,725
And so I'm just creating that, a primary
key non cluster ID and store, all right?

1377
01:13:24,725 --> 01:13:29,110
This'll ensure that I never have an order
ID that has the same store number.

1378
01:13:29,110 --> 01:13:33,620
With this model I could have order
number five at store one and

1379
01:13:33,620 --> 01:13:35,220
order number five at store two.

1380
01:13:35,220 --> 01:13:36,550
It would allow that, but

1381
01:13:36,550 --> 01:13:40,360
I couldn't have two order number
fives at store one, right?

1382
01:13:40,360 --> 01:13:42,010
And that's normally what we would want.

1383
01:13:42,010 --> 01:13:45,950
So this creates a primary key that
basically covers more than one column,

1384
01:13:45,950 --> 01:13:47,650
all right?

1385
01:13:47,650 --> 01:13:52,170
Now when you do that, the constraint has
to be built off of your partition scheme.

1386
01:13:52,170 --> 01:13:55,390
So that's what I'm doing here
is on partition scheme orders

1387
01:13:55,390 --> 01:13:58,180
with the store column being the partition.

1388
01:13:58,180 --> 01:14:03,460
And then the table itself is on the
partition scheme with the store column.

1389
01:14:03,460 --> 01:14:04,200
All right.

1390
01:14:04,200 --> 01:14:08,330
And then lastly, that's going
to create a non clustered index.

1391
01:14:08,330 --> 01:14:12,260
But clustered indexes will give us better
performance on a partition scheme.

1392
01:14:12,260 --> 01:14:15,140
So then, I just come back and
create another clustered index.

1393
01:14:15,140 --> 01:14:22,000
And I'm creating it on the store column,
again, attached to the partition scheme.

1394
01:14:22,000 --> 01:14:24,890
So, that's going to force
those to be in RAM, and

1395
01:14:24,890 --> 01:14:27,130
any time I run a query against the table.

1396
01:14:27,130 --> 01:14:30,960
Any time I go to add records to the table,
it's going to look at the order ID and

1397
01:14:30,960 --> 01:14:33,170
the store number, which are in RAM.

1398
01:14:33,170 --> 01:14:36,690
And then it will know exactly where to
go on the hard drive to find the data.

1399
01:14:36,690 --> 01:14:38,850
That's the key piece of optimization.

1400
01:14:38,850 --> 01:14:40,940
But, since the viewers hadn't
learned about indexes yet.

1401
01:14:40,940 --> 01:14:42,640
I didn't want to go into
that during the show.

1402
01:14:42,640 --> 01:14:44,940
So that's why it's here after the piece.

1403
01:14:44,940 --> 01:14:49,080
So if i take that right there and
execute it.

1404
01:14:49,080 --> 01:14:52,580
We'll see that it completes successfully
and over here i can refresh.

1405
01:14:52,580 --> 01:14:56,310
And now i'll have a nice happy
orders table right there

1406
01:14:56,310 --> 01:14:58,190
that is fully partitioned.

1407
01:14:58,190 --> 01:15:00,790
And the associated columns the I.D.

1408
01:15:00,790 --> 01:15:05,700
and the order of the store number, those
are in RAM optimized and ready to rock.

1409
01:15:05,700 --> 01:15:09,360
So that's the final piece, that's why
we got that aired during the show.

1410
01:15:09,360 --> 01:15:12,250
And why I didn't actually
cover how to fix it.

1411
01:15:12,250 --> 01:15:14,650
If you've already watched the index
episode, though, this'll cover it.

1412
01:15:14,650 --> 01:15:16,770
And I'll mention it in the index episode,
too.

1413
01:15:16,770 --> 01:15:19,820
But I just wanted to make sure you guys
kind of saw the completion of that.

1414
01:15:19,820 --> 01:15:22,300
I know that's important to some people.

1415
01:15:22,300 --> 01:15:24,440
All right.
Well, I hope you guys enjoyed it.

1416
01:15:24,440 --> 01:15:24,971
I'll see you next episode.

1417
01:15:24,971 --> 01:15:31,400
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Don demonstrates how to configure and activate the SQL Server Agent. He then shows how to schedule and automate various tasks using the SQL Agent.
episodes.title: SQL Server Agent
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,458 --> 00:00:36,271
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening.

3
00:00:36,271 --> 00:00:39,000
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:39,000 --> 00:00:44,040
I'm your host, Don Pezet back again with
another episode of Microsoft SQL Server.

5
00:00:44,040 --> 00:00:47,292
For those of you that are watching
live today is Apple announcement day.

6
00:00:47,292 --> 00:00:52,200
So what better way to recognize a new
Apple press release than not to talk about

7
00:00:52,200 --> 00:00:53,417
it at all, right?

8
00:00:53,417 --> 00:00:57,053
So [LAUGH] we're gonna dive into
Microsoft's SQL Server which is far more

9
00:00:57,053 --> 00:00:58,685
useful than a new iPhone.

10
00:00:58,685 --> 00:01:01,845
So [LAUGH] what we're gonna do today is
we're gonna look at some neat things that

11
00:01:01,845 --> 00:01:04,555
I kind of alluded to in earlier episodes.

12
00:01:04,555 --> 00:01:06,425
Now we're kinda get caught up.

13
00:01:06,425 --> 00:01:11,435
I've mentioned more than once how when
we're working with our databases and

14
00:01:11,435 --> 00:01:14,485
it's a one time activity, we use our GUI.

15
00:01:14,485 --> 00:01:16,170
We use our Graphical User Interface.

16
00:01:16,170 --> 00:01:18,390
We jump into our SQL Management Studio.

17
00:01:18,390 --> 00:01:20,900
We use our mouse, we right click,
we do our options,

18
00:01:20,900 --> 00:01:23,350
our settings, we're in, and we're done.

19
00:01:23,350 --> 00:01:27,120
But there are plenty of times
where we want to automate things,

20
00:01:27,120 --> 00:01:29,650
where we want things to happen later,
right?

21
00:01:29,650 --> 00:01:32,705
I want to make a change, but
I don't want it to happen until 2:00 am.

22
00:01:32,705 --> 00:01:37,370
But I don't want to be here at 2:00 am, I
just want the change to happen at 2:00 am.

23
00:01:37,370 --> 00:01:39,430
Well how do we go about automating that?

24
00:01:39,430 --> 00:01:42,980
And the way that we do
it in Microsoft SQLl is

25
00:01:42,980 --> 00:01:46,520
we use what is called
the SQL Server Agent.

26
00:01:46,520 --> 00:01:50,190
The SQL Server Agent is a process
that runs in the background, and

27
00:01:50,190 --> 00:01:51,710
it's our do boy.

28
00:01:51,710 --> 00:01:53,810
We tell it to do things and it does it.

29
00:01:53,810 --> 00:01:55,590
And it does them when we tell it to do it.

30
00:01:55,590 --> 00:01:58,500
So it's a neat way for
automating things or

31
00:01:58,500 --> 00:02:01,970
at least scheduling things to
occur when you are not around.

32
00:02:01,970 --> 00:02:06,160
Now when you're dealing with a database
there is a lot of stuff that can go wrong.

33
00:02:06,160 --> 00:02:09,890
So using the SQL Server Agent does
require a good bit of planning and

34
00:02:09,890 --> 00:02:13,150
it's a lot more advanced than
just scheduling software.

35
00:02:13,150 --> 00:02:15,730
It can do some really, really cool stuff.

36
00:02:15,730 --> 00:02:18,510
So I want to highlight some of those
features, some of those things.

37
00:02:18,510 --> 00:02:20,670
But, I also want to touch
on some of the pitfalls and

38
00:02:20,670 --> 00:02:25,430
the ways we can protect ourselves to
ensure that things execute properly or

39
00:02:25,430 --> 00:02:28,680
at least that we're notified in
the event a problem happens.

40
00:02:28,680 --> 00:02:30,960
There's actually a lot of
moving pieces in this one so

41
00:02:30,960 --> 00:02:32,830
we want to take a look at each of those.

42
00:02:32,830 --> 00:02:36,570
So, while the overall episode
is going to be talking about

43
00:02:36,570 --> 00:02:41,150
the sSQL Server Agent I've gotta talk
about a lot of add-on pieces, too,

44
00:02:41,150 --> 00:02:42,840
that make the agent better.

45
00:02:42,840 --> 00:02:45,430
So, we're gonna cover
a wide array of things, but

46
00:02:45,430 --> 00:02:49,640
at the end of the day, it's all gonna
tie back into that SQL Server Agent.

47
00:02:49,640 --> 00:02:53,180
Now, the agent is installed as
part of Microsoft SQL Server,

48
00:02:53,180 --> 00:02:57,090
so when you installed SQL Server,
it didn't even give you the option.

49
00:02:57,090 --> 00:03:00,410
I don't think you can choose
to not install the agent.

50
00:03:00,410 --> 00:03:03,520
But the agent is not turned on by default.

51
00:03:03,520 --> 00:03:05,830
So it was there during the installer.

52
00:03:05,830 --> 00:03:09,170
And you guys might remember, there
was a screen that was asking us about

53
00:03:09,170 --> 00:03:11,960
what user accounts we
wanted our services to use.

54
00:03:11,960 --> 00:03:15,960
And the SQL Server Agent was the only
one that didn't have an account listed.

55
00:03:15,960 --> 00:03:18,480
And it was set to manually start.

56
00:03:18,480 --> 00:03:22,260
That means that the SQL Server Agent
is just not enabled by default.

57
00:03:22,260 --> 00:03:24,710
The reason Microsoft does that is

58
00:03:24,710 --> 00:03:28,030
they don't know whether you're
going to use the agent or not.

59
00:03:28,030 --> 00:03:30,960
If you choose not to use the agent,
then they don't want it running.

60
00:03:30,960 --> 00:03:31,480
Sitting there,

61
00:03:31,480 --> 00:03:35,088
it's just one extra thing to increase
what's called your attack surface.

62
00:03:35,088 --> 00:03:37,850
Your attack surface is
anything an attacker could

63
00:03:37,850 --> 00:03:42,140
possibly use to exploit your server,
an agent is one of those things.

64
00:03:42,140 --> 00:03:45,630
The agent runs jobs under
a certain user account.

65
00:03:45,630 --> 00:03:49,050
If an attacker can find some way
to get the agent to run a job that

66
00:03:49,050 --> 00:03:53,400
they've designed, then now the agent is
performing actions with higher privileges.

67
00:03:53,400 --> 00:03:54,540
So it's privilege escalation.

68
00:03:54,540 --> 00:03:56,870
And that's not good, right.

69
00:03:56,870 --> 00:04:00,150
So Microsoft just leaves it disabled
by default and if you want to

70
00:04:00,150 --> 00:04:04,920
use the SQL Server Agent, you turn it on
and you get a set up to get what you need.

71
00:04:04,920 --> 00:04:08,590
So, that's gonna be mission number one
is just getting the SQL Server Agent

72
00:04:08,590 --> 00:04:09,280
up and running.

73
00:04:09,280 --> 00:04:15,570
Now, If you've only got one SQL Server,
just one database server; then typically

74
00:04:15,570 --> 00:04:19,540
what we'll do is we'll set up the agent
to run under a local system account.

75
00:04:19,540 --> 00:04:23,660
sight, So it'll just run as the system and
it'll perform it's jobs.

76
00:04:23,660 --> 00:04:27,088
But if you've got ten SQL Servers or
100 SQL Servers,

77
00:04:27,088 --> 00:04:31,530
you don't necessarily need to run
the agent on each and every one of them.

78
00:04:31,530 --> 00:04:34,810
In fact you can run the agent
on just one server.

79
00:04:34,810 --> 00:04:37,530
Large environments, enterprise
environments, where they've got tons of

80
00:04:37,530 --> 00:04:41,838
database servers, will typically
have dedicated agent servers.

81
00:04:41,838 --> 00:04:44,733
So a SQL server that doesn't
host any databases, well,

82
00:04:44,733 --> 00:04:48,370
no production databases, and
it just does the agent tasks, and so

83
00:04:48,370 --> 00:04:51,840
it's reaching out and remotely
executing things on the other servers.

84
00:04:51,840 --> 00:04:55,930
If you're going to do that, your
credentials become a real problem, right?

85
00:04:55,930 --> 00:04:57,250
User authentication.

86
00:04:57,250 --> 00:05:01,070
If the agent is running on
SQL server number one, and

87
00:05:01,070 --> 00:05:05,310
it's running on a local system account,
and it goes to SQL server number

88
00:05:05,310 --> 00:05:09,640
two to run a command, does it have
permissions on SQL Server number two?

89
00:05:09,640 --> 00:05:11,530
No, it doesn't, all right?

90
00:05:11,530 --> 00:05:14,920
So in that scenario,
we would need the SQL Server agent to run

91
00:05:14,920 --> 00:05:17,940
under a domain account,
an active directory domain account so

92
00:05:17,940 --> 00:05:20,565
that we could assign permissions
on each of the different servers.

93
00:05:20,565 --> 00:05:21,285
Servers.

94
00:05:21,285 --> 00:05:21,885
Right?

95
00:05:21,885 --> 00:05:24,845
So that's really where we start
with the SQL Server Agent is

96
00:05:24,845 --> 00:05:28,295
just getting it running and
setting up those account permissions.

97
00:05:28,295 --> 00:05:29,155
All right?

98
00:05:29,155 --> 00:05:33,045
If you fire up your service's
administrative tool.

99
00:05:33,045 --> 00:05:33,725
All right?

100
00:05:33,725 --> 00:05:38,885
So if I go under Tools and
Services, I can come in here and

101
00:05:38,885 --> 00:05:43,965
I can find the SQL Server Agent,
which is gonna be buried in here.

102
00:05:43,965 --> 00:05:44,665
Here it is.

103
00:05:44,665 --> 00:05:45,290
All right?

104
00:05:45,290 --> 00:05:48,990
Now notice I'm running more than
one instance of sequel server.

105
00:05:48,990 --> 00:05:51,360
I've got the main one,
my default instance, but

106
00:05:51,360 --> 00:05:55,410
I've also got the test sequel instance
we created in an earlier episode.

107
00:05:55,410 --> 00:05:59,065
There's a separate agent for
each instance.

108
00:05:59,065 --> 00:06:02,635
And that's because you'll probably want
separate permissions for each instance.

109
00:06:02,635 --> 00:06:04,545
That's why they're not tied together.

110
00:06:04,545 --> 00:06:06,915
You don't have to do that though.

111
00:06:06,915 --> 00:06:09,485
I could disable this agent and

112
00:06:09,485 --> 00:06:14,075
just use the first agent if it has
permissions to access the second instance.

113
00:06:14,075 --> 00:06:16,635
But I could just just one if I wanted.

114
00:06:16,635 --> 00:06:18,045
But Microsoft assumes, hey,

115
00:06:18,045 --> 00:06:22,480
if you're going to do separate instances,
you probably want separate agents also.

116
00:06:22,480 --> 00:06:23,240
All right.

117
00:06:23,240 --> 00:06:27,000
Now, during the install, I had told
my default instance to go ahead and

118
00:06:27,000 --> 00:06:28,880
start its agent, right.

119
00:06:28,880 --> 00:06:31,540
But for my test one, I didn't.

120
00:06:31,540 --> 00:06:35,740
And notice how it said here,
manually start up, and it's not running.

121
00:06:35,740 --> 00:06:39,540
If you do a default install of Microsoft
SQL Server, that's what you'll see.

122
00:06:39,540 --> 00:06:42,070
It'll have a manual start up and
it's not running.

123
00:06:42,070 --> 00:06:42,790
All right?

124
00:06:42,790 --> 00:06:47,910
Notice the account that it's using is an
NT service account/SQL agent, all right?

125
00:06:47,910 --> 00:06:50,810
And this one's using an NT Service
account/SQL server agent also, but

126
00:06:50,810 --> 00:06:52,770
they're separate service accounts.

127
00:06:52,770 --> 00:06:56,590
Those are the managed service
accounts that the Installer created.

128
00:06:56,590 --> 00:06:59,400
But they're local to this system.

129
00:06:59,400 --> 00:07:01,940
So if I want this to manage
more than one server,

130
00:07:01,940 --> 00:07:03,710
I probably want to switch
that to a domain account.

131
00:07:03,710 --> 00:07:05,280
So one of the first things
you'll do is you'll pull

132
00:07:05,280 --> 00:07:07,350
up the properties to that service.

133
00:07:07,350 --> 00:07:09,090
Go to the log on tab.

134

In my case though I've

A service account like this we can tailor

00:08:22,870 --> 00:08:24,820
Now the test one here

163
00:08:30,120 --> 00:08:34,630
Now it's not often, but
there are times when we might

164
00:08:34,630 --> 00:08:38,510
ask our SQL Server Agent to do something,
to perform some action and

165
00:08:38,510 --> 00:08:42,300
if we've written our script poorly or
if we're calling some other actions and

166
00:08:42,300 --> 00:08:46,210
it causes a crash,
the SQL Server Agent can crash, all right?

167
00:08:46,210 --> 00:08:51,920
If it crashes or locks up, all of your
scheduled jobs will stop running.

168
00:08:51,920 --> 00:08:53,930
Now that might not be
the end of the world.

169
00:08:53,930 --> 00:08:57,650

170
00:08:57,650 --> 00:08:59,850
I'll just do it tomorrow at 2 AM, right?

00:08:59,850 --> 00:09:02,040
But what if that automated
job is your backup?

172
00:09:02,040 --> 00:09:06,290
I'm backing up every 24 hours and
my backups crash and

173
00:09:06,290 --> 00:09:09,870
don't run because
the SQL Server Agent froze, right?

174
00:09:09,870 --> 00:09:12,700
Now, my backup window that was 24 hours

175
00:09:12,700 --> 00:09:15,710
just became 48 hours because
I missed a backup, right?

176
00:09:15,710 --> 00:09:16,890
So that'd be pretty bad.

177
00:09:16,890 --> 00:09:20,380
So it's a good idea to set recovery
settings on these services.

178
00:09:20,380 --> 00:09:23,790
If I take my SQL Server Agent here, and
I'm just doing the one for my default

179
00:09:23,790 --> 00:09:28,430
instance, and I go back into the
properties, you'll see this recovery tab.

180
00:09:28,430 --> 00:09:32,090

181
00:09:32,090 --> 00:09:37,790
If the agent locks up or if the agent
crashes and shuts down, the server

182
00:09:37,790 --> 00:09:42,980
makes a log entry but that's it,
it doesn't really do anything else, okay.

183
00:09:42,980 --> 00:09:47,830
So what we can do is we can tell it to try
and recover and what I like to do is if it

184
00:09:47,830 --> 00:09:53,690
fails restart, restart the service and
get it up and running again.

185
00:09:53,690 --> 00:09:58,250
It may have been just a fluke, some script
random crash but don't let that stop you

186
00:09:58,250 --> 00:10:01,430
from running your other things go ahead
and restart and get back in the saddle.

187
00:10:03,120 --> 00:10:06,360
If it crashes again, what do we do?

188
00:10:06,360 --> 00:10:08,580
Subsequent failures or
second failure and subsequent.

189
00:10:08,580 --> 00:10:09,570
What do we do?

190
00:10:09,570 --> 00:10:12,530
Well, the second time I might
just say try and restart again.

191
00:10:12,530 --> 00:10:13,840
Maybe one time's not enough right?

192
00:10:13,840 --> 00:10:15,000
We'll try and restart twice.

193
00:10:16,400 --> 00:10:23,070
But if it's still not working, if it
crashes again then what do we do finally,

194
00:10:23,070 --> 00:10:26,090
and you can be really aggressive here and
say restart the computer.

195
00:10:26,090 --> 00:10:30,260
If the agent crashes twice just go
ahead and reboot the whole server.

196
00:10:31,300 --> 00:10:35,300
That might be a little too aggressive
though if you've got a 24/7 system.

197
00:10:35,300 --> 00:10:38,460
We are just talking about the agent,
so the agent might have crashed but

198
00:10:38,460 --> 00:10:40,100
the database is still online.

199
00:10:40,100 --> 00:10:42,430
Users can get to the database and
access data.

200
00:10:42,430 --> 00:10:45,340
So, rebooting the server might
be a little heavy handed.

201
00:10:45,340 --> 00:10:50,450
Instead I might want to perform some
other action, like, Run a Program.

202
00:10:50,450 --> 00:10:54,160
With Run a Program you call a script or
executable or

203
00:10:54,160 --> 00:10:56,490
whatever, which can do anything.

204
00:10:56,490 --> 00:10:58,450
You can have it shoot you an email,

205
00:10:58,450 --> 00:11:01,000
you can have it take a backup
of the server you can have it do

206
00:11:01,000 --> 00:11:04,870
all sorts of crazy things, it's only
limited to what you can write in a script.

207
00:11:04,870 --> 00:11:11,220
So you can call all sorts of stuff there
and really do some neat things with it.

208
00:11:11,220 --> 00:11:15,710
I've done simple email notifications to
let me know hey this thing failed and

209
00:11:15,710 --> 00:11:17,150
here's the failure account.

210
00:11:17,150 --> 00:11:19,350
See how you can upend that
failure account to the end.

211
00:11:19,350 --> 00:11:22,080
So you can do simple things like that,
real easy to do and

212
00:11:22,080 --> 00:11:23,120
get those notifications.

213
00:11:24,530 --> 00:11:28,950
Now when we say restart the service here,
when it goes from first failure to second

214
00:11:28,950 --> 00:11:32,150
failure to subsequent failure,
we need to pay attention to this.

215
00:11:32,150 --> 00:11:33,620
Reset fail count after.

216
00:11:34,910 --> 00:11:38,300
Now, what this setting does is it says

217
00:11:38,300 --> 00:11:41,970
how far in between the crashes
do I count a first and a second.

218
00:11:43,160 --> 00:11:47,082
If we set this to one day,
if I have a freeze one day,

219
00:11:47,082 --> 00:11:52,550
it'll restart, and if I have
a freeze about on the second day.

220
00:11:52,550 --> 00:11:57,460
Well that's 24 hours later, so that's
actually viewed as a first failure, right,

221
00:11:57,460 --> 00:12:00,890
because I have it set to reset
the fail count every one day.

222
00:12:00,890 --> 00:12:05,920
So I would have to have two freezes in
this same day to count as the second

223
00:12:05,920 --> 00:12:10,470
failure, and three freezes in the same
day to actually get to Run a Program.

224
00:12:11,780 --> 00:12:16,510
But I might want to stretch that
out longer to go for three days.

225
00:12:16,510 --> 00:12:21,830
So if I have a freeze one day, and
a freeze the next day and a 3rd day.

226
00:12:21,830 --> 00:12:25,020
That would be the subsequent failure that
would cause to run a program because it

227
00:12:25,020 --> 00:12:26,595
all happened in that three day windows.

228
00:12:26,595 --> 00:12:28,780
So that's something we
might want to adjust and

229
00:12:28,780 --> 00:12:32,780
you can also set a delay, how long to
wait before restarting the service.

230
00:12:32,780 --> 00:12:36,910
If there's been a freeze do we
restart it right away or do we wait?

231
00:12:36,910 --> 00:12:39,830
And you can put in your zero minutes,
one minute, you know whatever it is you

232
00:12:39,830 --> 00:12:42,790
want to wait before you actually
kick that service into restart.

233
00:12:44,690 --> 00:12:48,350
All right, so these are a couple
of neat things we can do here.

234
00:12:48,350 --> 00:12:51,820
You'll see also you get the enable
actions for stops with errors so

235
00:12:51,820 --> 00:12:53,640
we can tell it a few other options.

236
00:12:53,640 --> 00:12:56,480
There's different settings in here based
on what it is we're trying to achieve.

237
00:12:56,480 --> 00:13:00,760
For the most part, though, we usually just
want to restart the service and, in fact,

238
00:13:00,760 --> 00:13:02,910
I'm gonna say go ahead and restart it.

239
00:13:02,910 --> 00:13:06,450
If it still doesn't work after a restart,
I'll just say take no action.

240
00:13:06,450 --> 00:13:08,640
And then we'll put that back to one day.

241
00:13:10,050 --> 00:13:14,489
All right, so those are some good options
to set there just to make sure that

242
00:13:14,489 --> 00:13:16,050
the agent stays running.

It's no big deal It doesn't let

database so

01:29:02,560 --> 01:29:04,980

01:29:06,310 --> 01:29:07,310

01:29:18,950 --> 01:29:19,900

01:29:23,090 --> 01:29:25,670

01:29:32,990 --> 01:29:34,250

1722
01:29:34,250 --> 01:29:35,540

1723
01:29:36,880 --> 01:29:38,870

1724
01:29:38,870 --> 01:29:43,470
The blue arrow is saying if

1725
01:29:43,470 --> 01:29:46,980
The red arrow is saying if the step fails,

1726
01:29:46,980 --> 01:29:51,710
So if I can't access the flat file source

1727
01:29:51,710 --> 01:29:57,930
an activity to do something like cause
an alert, or something like that.

1728
01:29:57,930 --> 01:30:00,920
A script component to send an email or
whatever.

1729
01:30:00,920 --> 01:30:06,610
So I might come in and

1730
01:30:06,610 --> 01:30:11,408
And so now, if for some reason it
fails to access the file source,

1731
01:30:11,408 --> 01:30:13,510

1732

1733

right, or if any of these fail,

1738

1740

1741

DBAs, we're not normally developers.

1743
01:30:47,050 --> 01:30:50,340
So we don't need that skill
set to come in and do this.

1744
01:30:50,340 --> 01:30:52,070
And that was all just one data flow.

Right?

1746
01:30:52,650 --> 01:30:54,910
I could then add more data flows to it.

1747

1753
01:31:13,840 --> 01:31:18,440

1754
01:31:18,440 --> 01:31:19,810
That's the power of SSIS.

1755
01:31:19,810 --> 01:31:22,250
That's what it can do,
tons of stuff in there.

1756
01:31:22,250 --> 01:31:25,820
Those database management plans,

It's our extra assistant in

1772

seven days a week, great resource to use,

1773

All right, well that's a good spot for

1774

episodes.description: In this episode Don walks you through the process of backing up and restoring databases in Microsoft SQL. He explains the difference between full, differential and transaction log backups and describes when to use each.
episodes.title: Backup and Restore Databases
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,040 --> 00:00:10,040
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:15,260 --> 00:00:22,510
[SOUND]

3
00:00:22,510 --> 00:00:32,510
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,750 --> 00:00:36,785
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening and

5
00:00:36,785 --> 00:00:38,970
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:38,970 --> 00:00:43,718
I'm your host, Don Pezet back in with
another episode of Microsoft SQL.

7
00:00:43,718 --> 00:00:48,149
Today, we're gonna be jumping into backing
up and restoring our databases and

8
00:00:48,149 --> 00:00:52,247
that means that this episode is probably
one of the most important in terms

9
00:00:52,247 --> 00:00:55,840
of the job duties you're gonna
have out there in the real world.

10
00:00:55,840 --> 00:00:59,039
There is no substitute for
a good backup of a database and

11
00:00:59,039 --> 00:01:01,626
when things go wrong boy,
having that backup

12
00:01:01,626 --> 00:01:06,340
is gonna make the difference between you
keeping your job and you losing your job.

13
00:01:06,340 --> 00:01:10,220
We call these Resume Generating Events,
RGEs.

14
00:01:10,220 --> 00:01:12,929
If you have a failure and
you lose a database,

15
00:01:12,929 --> 00:01:16,496
databases have become so
critical to companies that losing

16
00:01:16,496 --> 00:01:19,870
them is oftentimes catastrophic
to the organization.

17
00:01:19,870 --> 00:01:23,164
So we need to make sure that we
have a good backup system in place,

18
00:01:23,164 --> 00:01:27,511
that it's being done and we're monitoring
it to make sure that the backups happen.

19
00:01:27,511 --> 00:01:31,092
And then we also need to make sure
that we've tested our restores, so

20
00:01:31,092 --> 00:01:35,130
that we know the restores are working and
that that data is functioning also.

21
00:01:35,130 --> 00:01:37,670
It's very, very important.

22
00:01:37,670 --> 00:01:41,273
So that's what we're gonna spend this
episode on we're gonna dive into it deep

23
00:01:41,273 --> 00:01:44,661
here and make sure we've got a really
good understanding of the process and

24
00:01:44,661 --> 00:01:47,920
that we are comfortable with getting
our systems backup in operation.

25
00:01:47,920 --> 00:01:52,590
So let's start with something simple,
which is just doing a backup.

26
00:01:52,590 --> 00:01:55,840
Backing up a SQL database
is actually really easy.

27
00:01:55,840 --> 00:01:58,236
SQL has its own native
backup built into it, so

28
00:01:58,236 --> 00:02:01,748
we don't need special third party
software or anything like that.

29
00:02:01,748 --> 00:02:06,128
We can backup and dump our data
to a couple of different places.

30
00:02:06,128 --> 00:02:08,008
Normally, we're backing
up to the hard drive.

31
00:02:08,008 --> 00:02:11,468
Now obviously, backing up to the hard
drive is right here on the SQL servers is

32
00:02:11,468 --> 00:02:13,130
not the greatest thing in the world.

33
00:02:13,130 --> 00:02:15,999
So typically,
you backup to the hard drives and

34
00:02:15,999 --> 00:02:18,590
then shift those backups somewhere else.

35
00:02:18,590 --> 00:02:22,901
Maybe there you use third party backup
software to take care of managing that or

36
00:02:22,901 --> 00:02:25,720
whatever, but
we need to at least get that backup.

37
00:02:25,720 --> 00:02:29,680
SQL also supports backing up directly to a
tape drive, so if you're still using tapes

38
00:02:29,680 --> 00:02:33,420
for backup, you can do that too, it's
got the native support for it built-in.

39
00:02:33,420 --> 00:02:36,555
It's been a long time since I've had
to use a tape, I used to use them

40
00:02:36,555 --> 00:02:39,920
all the time, but almost everybody's
gone to replicated storage now.

41
00:02:39,920 --> 00:02:43,640
So you'll usually backup to a network
appliance on your network and

42
00:02:43,640 --> 00:02:47,175
then that appliance will typically
replicate somewhere else.

43
00:02:47,175 --> 00:02:51,345
SQL has got full support for that, so
we don't need anything special to do it.

44
00:02:51,345 --> 00:02:55,215
So we need to think about that,
where are we gonna put our backups?

45
00:02:55,215 --> 00:03:00,675
Now on this particular server,
what I've got are multiple hard drives.

46
00:03:00,675 --> 00:03:04,045
And so I've got my C drive,
which is where my operating system is.

47
00:03:04,045 --> 00:03:07,465
I've got my D drive, where I've
been putting my transaction logs.

48
00:03:07,465 --> 00:03:11,065
I've got my E drive where my databases
have been going and I've got yet

49
00:03:11,065 --> 00:03:14,800
another physical hard drive,
a 500 gig hard drive here for backups.

50
00:03:14,800 --> 00:03:17,300
I'm gonna back up to a completely
separate hard drive.

51
00:03:17,300 --> 00:03:21,168
That means that if I lose my database
drive or my transaction log drive,

52
00:03:21,168 --> 00:03:23,630
I lose one of these guys,
I'll be all right.

53
00:03:23,630 --> 00:03:26,550
My backups are over here,
I can recover them.

54
00:03:26,550 --> 00:03:30,824
But if I lose the server itself,
if I have a building fire, for example,

55
00:03:30,824 --> 00:03:32,800
that's not going to protect me.

56
00:03:32,800 --> 00:03:35,712
But that's okay, cuz what I can
do is I can take that G drive and

57
00:03:35,712 --> 00:03:38,130
I can just replicate that
storage somewhere else.

58
00:03:38,130 --> 00:03:40,590
So I can back it up and
send it wherever I need to, but

59
00:03:40,590 --> 00:03:43,130
that's basically where my
backups are going to go.

60
00:03:43,130 --> 00:03:47,220
Now it is just an empty drive here,
nothing to special on it.

61
00:03:47,220 --> 00:03:50,917
Let me check the permissions on that
folder real quick just to make sure It's

62
00:03:50,917 --> 00:03:52,260
a little bit limited here.

63
00:03:52,260 --> 00:03:55,130
Let me just bump that up a bit.

64
00:03:55,130 --> 00:03:57,350
So we're gonna be backing
up to this location,

65
00:03:57,350 --> 00:03:59,800
I just made a little folder
here to put my backups in.

66
00:03:59,800 --> 00:04:04,260
And again, you can just figure out where
it is you wanna put it on your network.

67
00:04:04,260 --> 00:04:05,970
So I'm gonna pop it right here.

68
00:04:05,970 --> 00:04:08,630
Now, then we just need
to tell SQL to do it.

69
00:04:08,630 --> 00:04:12,078
If you're just doing a one time backup,
it's really straightforward,

70
00:04:12,078 --> 00:04:14,426
we just run through and
complete a simple wizard.

71
00:04:14,426 --> 00:04:18,800
If we wanna setup a backup schedule
though, we've got a few choices.

72
00:04:18,800 --> 00:04:23,070
Choice number one is we can create
a script to backup the system and

73
00:04:23,070 --> 00:04:26,260
then we can create a SQL
server agent job to do it.

74
00:04:26,260 --> 00:04:29,731
So if you haven't watched it already, we
did an episode on the SQL server agent and

75
00:04:29,731 --> 00:04:32,470
how to automate that type of activity,
so you can do it that way.

76
00:04:32,470 --> 00:04:36,260
The other option is you can do what's
called a database maintenance plan.

77
00:04:36,260 --> 00:04:40,422
When you do a database maintenance plan,
it will setup the backups for you and

78
00:04:40,422 --> 00:04:44,340
setup the schedule and all of that, so
it does it all wrapped up into one.

79
00:04:44,340 --> 00:04:46,380
That's kind of nice and
you can go that route.

80
00:04:46,380 --> 00:04:48,849
We cover that in a SQL
server agent episode also so

81
00:04:48,849 --> 00:04:51,750
if you haven't seen it just jump over and
catch that one.

82
00:04:51,750 --> 00:04:55,532
But let's take a look at doing it
manually, because I wanna make sure you

83
00:04:55,532 --> 00:04:59,066
guys understand exactly what's
happening as the backups occur and

84
00:04:59,066 --> 00:05:01,800
what all the different
options are that we've got.

85
00:05:01,800 --> 00:05:05,281
The first thing we need to remember is
when we do a backup our database is

86
00:05:05,281 --> 00:05:06,880
actually split into two files.

87
00:05:06,880 --> 00:05:08,260
Well, it could be split into many.

88
00:05:08,260 --> 00:05:10,590
But at a minimum,
it's split into two files.

89
00:05:10,590 --> 00:05:15,040
You've got your database file,
the MDF, the main database file.

90
00:05:15,040 --> 00:05:20,010
And you've got the transaction log file,
the LDF or the log database file.

91
00:05:20,010 --> 00:05:23,590
So the LDF and the MDF,
those are your main files.

92
00:05:23,590 --> 00:05:27,790
You may also have file groups and so
you may have a bunch of NDF files,

93
00:05:27,790 --> 00:05:30,886
secondary files that contain tables or
row sets or

94
00:05:30,886 --> 00:05:34,590
whatever it is that you've got
stuck in those other files.

95
00:05:34,590 --> 00:05:36,590
But at a minimum,
we've got these two main files.

96
00:05:36,590 --> 00:05:40,130
And so when we do our backups,
we've gotta back up these files.

97
00:05:40,130 --> 00:05:40,920
That is important.

98
00:05:40,920 --> 00:05:44,917
We've gotta make sure that we understand
that we're gathering that data and

99
00:05:44,917 --> 00:05:48,800
backing it up and storing it somewhere and
that we get it in a complete form.

100
00:05:48,800 --> 00:05:51,644
It's real easy to end up with
a backup that's incomplete and

101
00:05:51,644 --> 00:05:55,378
it won't be useful for you to restore
from, you'll be in a moment of failure and

102
00:05:55,378 --> 00:05:56,970
your backups will be worthless.

103
00:05:56,970 --> 00:06:00,120
So that's why we've got to plan for
this really, really well.

104
00:06:00,120 --> 00:06:03,471
Now before we even start taking backups,

105
00:06:03,471 --> 00:06:09,130
we need to understand that databases
run in one of three backup modes.

106
00:06:09,130 --> 00:06:12,380
If I take a database,
like my products database.

107
00:06:12,380 --> 00:06:15,566
Let me just pull up the Properties
on my products database and

108
00:06:15,566 --> 00:06:18,811
if I look at my files here,
I can see the files that I've got and

109
00:06:18,811 --> 00:06:21,510
I guess I didn't move these
off to the other drive.

110
00:06:21,510 --> 00:06:25,260
So these are all on my C drive, but
I've got my various files there.

111
00:06:25,260 --> 00:06:29,316
But if I go down to Options,
here under the options screen,

112
00:06:29,316 --> 00:06:31,762
I'll see some interesting stuff.

113
00:06:31,762 --> 00:06:36,502
Right up here, there,
you can see my collation and

114
00:06:36,502 --> 00:06:40,920
compatibility and so
on, but recovery model.

115
00:06:40,920 --> 00:06:45,150
There are three different recovery
models that SQL operates under.

116
00:06:45,150 --> 00:06:48,710
And these recovery models are going
to affect how we do our backups and

117
00:06:48,710 --> 00:06:49,970
how we do our restores.

118
00:06:51,240 --> 00:06:55,790
When you do a backup, if you are in
the full recovery model, the full recovery

119
00:06:55,790 --> 00:07:02,090
model will backup the database and
the transaction logs.

120
00:07:02,090 --> 00:07:04,839
It allows you to work with
the transaction logs to

121
00:07:04,839 --> 00:07:07,800
be able to do what are called
point in time restores.

122
00:07:07,800 --> 00:07:10,135
Point in time restores are important,

123
00:07:10,135 --> 00:07:13,470
because you might not have
a lot of time do full backups.

124
00:07:13,470 --> 00:07:17,590
A full backup of your database,
that's where you backup the entire thing.

125
00:07:17,590 --> 00:07:21,013
If you have a failure, you can go
to a full backup and restore it and

126
00:07:21,013 --> 00:07:24,260
you're back in business, right,
you got the whole backup.

127
00:07:24,260 --> 00:07:26,528
But if your database
is a terabyte in size,

128
00:07:26,528 --> 00:07:28,550
it may take a while to do a full backup.

Now that means that each differential

Once I have this differential

Now the reason I mention that is

So that's an example of doing

I mean,

00:25:52,900 --> 00:25:55,930
Now, transaction log backups are different

00:25:55,930 --> 00:26:00,130

00:26:00,130 --> 00:26:01,310

Differentials, see how it gets bigger and

00:26:07,400 --> 00:26:10,150
Cuz it has all the changes

00:26:10,150 --> 00:26:14,030
With transaction log backups,

00:26:14,030 --> 00:26:15,690
They don't actually like delete them.

00:26:15,690 --> 00:26:17,180
They just empty them out, so

00:26:17,180 --> 00:26:21,280
they're flushing or clearing

00:26:21,280 --> 00:26:24,270
So each of these backups that's occurring,

00:26:24,270 --> 00:26:29,160
they're not like what we saw a moment ago

00:26:29,160 --> 00:26:32,100
They've just got a subset of data.

00:26:32,100 --> 00:26:36,330
They've got the data since

00:26:36,330 --> 00:26:37,600
Not since the last full.

00:26:38,690 --> 00:26:44,160
So like this guy here doesn't actually

00:26:48,170 --> 00:26:51,520
each one is just going back

00:26:51,520 --> 00:26:52,680
All right.

00:26:52,680 --> 00:26:57,240
On a positive side,

00:27:13,770 --> 00:27:17,380

00:27:18,640 --> 00:27:22,220

Can you not afford to lose any data?

1704
01:29:39,210 --> 01:29:41,990
Well you need to have
the full recovery model.

1705
01:29:41,990 --> 01:29:45,997
You need to be doing transaction log
backups every 5 minutes, 15 minutes,

1706
01:29:45,997 --> 01:29:48,546
whatever, how often you need,
to ensure you've

1707
01:29:48,546 --> 01:29:52,270
got backups of your data to lose as
little data as possible when you fail.

1708
01:29:52,270 --> 01:29:53,730
There are other solutions out there.

1709
01:29:53,730 --> 01:29:57,610
There is SQL replication, which we'll
actually talk about in another episode.

1710
01:29:57,610 --> 01:30:00,554
And SQL clustering, so
we can have multiple servers involved when

1711
01:30:00,554 --> 01:30:02,600
a database fails and
another one's right there.

1712
01:30:02,600 --> 01:30:04,730
Those protect you from hardware failure,

1713
01:30:04,730 --> 01:30:06,840
they don't protect you from
your end users though.

1714
01:30:06,840 --> 01:30:10,303
In a replicated database,
if somebody drops a table on one server,

1715
01:30:10,303 --> 01:30:13,600
that replicates to the other side and
drops the table there too.

1716
01:30:13,600 --> 01:30:17,600
Now we will learn about database snapshots
later on too, they can help, but

1717
01:30:17,600 --> 01:30:19,860
there's no substitute for a good backup.

1718
01:30:19,860 --> 01:30:24,560
The things we talked about in this episode
are things that every company should do.

1719
01:30:24,560 --> 01:30:26,620
All right,
well that pretty much wraps up backups.

1720
01:30:26,620 --> 01:30:31,336
So let me just remind you guys, if you
have questions on any of that, just ask,

1721
01:30:31,336 --> 01:30:31,840
right?

1722
01:30:31,840 --> 01:30:34,458
Live during the show you
can go to itpro.tv/live,

1723
01:30:34,458 --> 01:30:37,420
you'll see the chat box
right beneath the video.

1724
01:30:37,420 --> 01:30:40,800
Post your questions there,
we monitor and answer during the show.

1725
01:30:40,800 --> 01:30:43,990
If you have questions after the show,
use our Q&A forums.

1726
01:30:43,990 --> 01:30:47,526
At the top of every page is a link that
says Q&A, you can jump right in there,

1727
01:30:47,526 --> 01:30:49,650
post your question, we monitor and answer.

1728
01:30:49,650 --> 01:30:54,010
So one way or another,
we will get your questions taken care of.

1729
01:30:54,010 --> 01:30:55,850
Well I hope you guys enjoyed the show.

1730
01:30:55,850 --> 01:31:00,040
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet and
I will see you next time.

1731
01:31:00,040 --> 01:31:10,040
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Don shows various methods for getting data into and out of SQL. He wraps up by showing how to use indexes with your data to significantly improve performance.
episodes.title: Import, Export, and Indexing Data
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,103 --> 00:00:10,103
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,535 --> 00:00:34,139
All right.

3
00:00:34,139 --> 00:00:36,677
Good morning, good afternoon,
and good evening, and

4
00:00:36,677 --> 00:00:38,730
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:38,730 --> 00:00:43,990
I'm your host Don Pezet, back again
with another episode of Microsoft SQL.

6
00:00:43,990 --> 00:00:46,650
Today we're gonna diving be
into some neat things that we

7
00:00:46,650 --> 00:00:49,700
just really haven't addressed so
far but are pretty important.

8
00:00:49,700 --> 00:00:53,790
We're gonna start off taking a look
at getting data into our database.

9
00:00:53,790 --> 00:00:57,070
All through this series, right, we've
filmed quite a few episodes at this point

10
00:00:57,070 --> 00:01:00,420
and all of them have centered around
creating the database server and

11
00:01:00,420 --> 00:01:04,200
getting our infrastructure in place, and
backups and restores and stuff like that.

12
00:01:04,200 --> 00:01:08,600
But we've never actually put
any data into our database yet.

13
00:01:08,600 --> 00:01:09,536
So we need to see about that.

14
00:01:09,536 --> 00:01:12,414
So we're gonna get a chance to see
sticking data into the database.

15
00:01:12,414 --> 00:01:17,106
We're also gonna take a look at how we can
optimize that data to make our server run

16
00:01:17,106 --> 00:01:17,663
faster.

17
00:01:17,663 --> 00:01:21,519
So when we start to bring in
information as a systems administrator,

18
00:01:21,519 --> 00:01:25,637
a lot of times they're gonna tell you
hey I need you to create a database and

19
00:01:25,637 --> 00:01:29,377
here's the data I want you to stick
in there and you pop it in there.

20
00:01:29,377 --> 00:01:33,176
Well, you could stop there, but
typically, we go a little bit further and

21
00:01:33,176 --> 00:01:37,214
say now that I've got the data, how can I
make my server run as fast as possible,

22
00:01:37,214 --> 00:01:40,690
how can I really optimize the queries
that my developers are using?

23
00:01:40,690 --> 00:01:43,340
Cuz the developers don't necessarily
know how to do that themselves.

24
00:01:43,340 --> 00:01:45,810
So that's what we're gonna
look at in this episode, and

25
00:01:45,810 --> 00:01:48,380
we'll kinda start off with
getting our data in here.

26
00:01:48,380 --> 00:01:51,925
So I've been working with a sample
database all through this series and

27
00:01:51,925 --> 00:01:55,010
It looks like we kind of left a bit
of a mess in the last episode.

28
00:01:55,010 --> 00:01:57,400
I've got one data base
that's still restoring.

29
00:01:57,400 --> 00:01:58,720
I'm gonna ignore it.

30
00:01:59,770 --> 00:02:04,320
But we got like a products data base
here and in my products data base I can

31
00:02:04,320 --> 00:02:08,020
drill down and see tables that we've
created, and I don't have any.

32
00:02:08,020 --> 00:02:12,380
Well, a database without any tables
is not much of a database at all.

33
00:02:12,380 --> 00:02:14,060
So I need to get in here and

34
00:02:14,060 --> 00:02:17,210
start to create some tables and
get some data put in.

35
00:02:17,210 --> 00:02:18,160
I can do it by hand.

36
00:02:18,160 --> 00:02:18,700
Right?

37
00:02:18,700 --> 00:02:21,220
If I want to create my own table,
I can do that.

38
00:02:21,220 --> 00:02:23,780
I just right click here on tables and
go to New Table.

39
00:02:25,170 --> 00:02:29,180
And it asks us for the various columns
that are gonna be in that table.

40
00:02:29,180 --> 00:02:31,940
Now, notice it's not asking for
a table name.

41
00:02:31,940 --> 00:02:34,200
When I save it,
it'll ask for a table name.

42
00:02:34,200 --> 00:02:37,380
Or if I wanna enter it ahead of time,
I can go over here to Properties, and

43
00:02:37,380 --> 00:02:38,450
the table name is right here.

44
00:02:38,450 --> 00:02:40,710
It's just defaulting
to table underscore 1.

45
00:02:40,710 --> 00:02:42,800
We can call it whatever we want.

46
00:02:42,800 --> 00:02:45,990
So, for example,
if this is my products database,

47
00:02:45,990 --> 00:02:49,040
I probably need a products table that'll
have a list of all of my products.

48
00:02:49,040 --> 00:02:50,770
So I can come in here and create one.

49
00:02:50,770 --> 00:02:55,630
I'll call this my Products table.

50
00:02:55,630 --> 00:02:59,340
And what are some of the column types that
we might have for something like products?

51
00:02:59,340 --> 00:03:02,880
Well we probably wanna have
some kind of ID number

52
00:03:02,880 --> 00:03:05,810
that will represent each
product numerically.

53
00:03:05,810 --> 00:03:08,920
ID numbers are really important for
doing things like cross referencing.

54
00:03:08,920 --> 00:03:13,280
When somebody buys ten different products
I don't want to store the full product

55
00:03:13,280 --> 00:03:14,060
name for each one.

56
00:03:14,060 --> 00:03:15,480
Instead I just wanna store a number.

57
00:03:15,480 --> 00:03:18,460
They purchased item number 5,
item number 7, and item number 33.

58
00:03:18,460 --> 00:03:22,380
And then we can do lookups to
say what is item number 33?

59
00:03:22,380 --> 00:03:23,700
And we would pull that from here.

60
00:03:23,700 --> 00:03:26,170
So each product that we have
would have an ID number.

61
00:03:27,200 --> 00:03:29,610
We'd also have something like a name for
the product.

62
00:03:30,890 --> 00:03:33,280
Maybe a description of the product.

63
00:03:33,280 --> 00:03:36,650
And maybe we have short descriptions and
long descriptions.

64
00:03:36,650 --> 00:03:41,350
So there might be some real quick
one sentence short description

65
00:03:42,450 --> 00:03:45,630
which is just a quick easy
note about what this item is.

66
00:03:45,630 --> 00:03:48,300
And then we might have
a long description which is

67
00:03:48,300 --> 00:03:52,500
very in depth detailing all the pros and
cons of that product.

68
00:03:52,500 --> 00:03:54,870
We probably also need to know a price.

69
00:03:54,870 --> 00:03:56,780
How much that product is gonna cost.

70
00:03:56,780 --> 00:03:59,570
We might need to know
whether it's taxable or not.

71
00:03:59,570 --> 00:04:01,110
Different countries have different rules.

72
00:04:01,110 --> 00:04:04,540
In Europe some products have VAT applied,
some products don't.

73
00:04:04,540 --> 00:04:07,090
Here in the US some products are taxable,
some aren't.

74
00:04:07,090 --> 00:04:09,410
So like a lot of food
stuffs are non taxable.

75
00:04:09,410 --> 00:04:13,890
So we might have a taxable column,
this stores yes or no as to whether or

76
00:04:13,890 --> 00:04:15,850
not that item is taxable.

77
00:04:15,850 --> 00:04:19,710
So we just come through and we define
what those columns are gonna be for

78
00:04:19,710 --> 00:04:21,720
our products, right?

79
00:04:21,720 --> 00:04:24,470
Now, notice the data types over here.

80
00:04:24,470 --> 00:04:27,450
Every column stores
a certain amount of data.

81
00:04:27,450 --> 00:04:30,610
And in SQL we have two different
main types of data types.

82
00:04:30,610 --> 00:04:33,360
There's fixed data types,
which all of these are.

83
00:04:33,360 --> 00:04:35,980
And then there's variable data types.

84
00:04:35,980 --> 00:04:40,700
A fixed data type, the database knows
exactly how big it's going to be.

85
00:04:40,700 --> 00:04:43,580
See how these say, nchar(10), right.

86
00:04:43,580 --> 00:04:49,630
So that is a text character, and it's
gonna hold up to ten characters, right?

87
00:04:49,630 --> 00:04:50,600
Ten is the maximum.

88
00:04:50,600 --> 00:04:52,360
It's a fixed size of ten.

89
00:04:52,360 --> 00:04:57,680
So I can store between zero and
ten letters inside of this field.

90
00:04:57,680 --> 00:05:02,160
Now, for something like a product name,
ten characters is probably not enough.

91
00:05:02,160 --> 00:05:04,550
And so I might need to make this bigger.

92
00:05:04,550 --> 00:05:08,920
Now, with a fixed field like this,
the database says,

93
00:05:08,920 --> 00:05:14,080
I don't care if you store one letter or
ten letters, when I write it to the file,

94
00:05:14,080 --> 00:05:18,740
it's gonna take ten spaces, ten bytes,
or whatever, ten values, ten characters.

95
00:05:18,740 --> 00:05:23,440
So that way the database always knows
exactly how big that data is gonna be, and

96
00:05:23,440 --> 00:05:25,290
it's very, very efficient.

97
00:05:25,290 --> 00:05:28,950
For the most part, you want to use
fixed data types whenever you can.

98
00:05:30,390 --> 00:05:33,380
However, there's times where fixed
data types don't work out, for

99
00:05:33,380 --> 00:05:36,020
example with the long description.

100
00:05:36,020 --> 00:05:40,160
If my long description
could be 50 characters,

101
00:05:40,160 --> 00:05:43,210
could be 5,000 characters,
Could be 50,000 characters.

102
00:05:43,210 --> 00:05:45,300
Depends on how much I was willing
to write about that product.

103
00:05:45,300 --> 00:05:47,510
I really don't know how
big it is going to be.

104
00:05:47,510 --> 00:05:50,437
And so if I pick a really big fixed value,

105
00:05:50,437 --> 00:05:54,410
I might be wasting a lot
of space in my database.

106
00:05:54,410 --> 00:05:57,490
And so for
those I might want to make it variable.

107
00:05:57,490 --> 00:06:02,700
And with a variable character, or a
variable data type, it says you can store

108
00:06:02,700 --> 00:06:07,300
up to this amount, you still specify
a maximum, but you don't have a minimum.

109
00:06:07,300 --> 00:06:11,200
You can specify as few as you want and
that's all the space you'll take.

110
00:06:11,200 --> 00:06:11,880
So for

111
00:06:11,880 --> 00:06:16,685
example with the short description, maybe
I say that that's going to be a nchar.

112
00:06:16,685 --> 00:06:18,810
We'll say 120, okay, so

113
00:06:18,810 --> 00:06:23,497
the short description can't
have more than 120 characters.

114
00:06:23,497 --> 00:06:25,551
Or you know what,
let's go Twitter, what is Twitter?

115
00:06:25,551 --> 00:06:27,931
It's like 143, isn't it?

116
00:06:27,931 --> 00:06:30,369
So we'll say nchar(143).

117
00:06:30,369 --> 00:06:34,932
So now it'll know that I can store
data in here up to 143 characters.

118
00:06:34,932 --> 00:06:37,294
But if I store 100 characters in there,

119
00:06:37,294 --> 00:06:40,480
it'll still consume the same
amount of space as 143.

120
00:06:40,480 --> 00:06:41,870
But for the long description,

121
00:06:41,870 --> 00:06:45,810
if I drop that down you'll
see I've got nv character 50.

122
00:06:45,810 --> 00:06:47,500
All right?

123
00:06:47,500 --> 00:06:51,304
And I can change that 50 to whatever and
maybe I'll make it 5,000.

124
00:06:51,304 --> 00:06:52,198
All right?

125
00:06:52,198 --> 00:06:54,500
This one, oop, 4,000's my highest.

126
00:06:54,500 --> 00:06:56,440
Let me fix that.

127
00:06:56,440 --> 00:06:57,690
Every data type has a maximum.

128
00:06:57,690 --> 00:06:58,650
I just went over the maximum.

129
00:06:58,650 --> 00:06:59,770
So I'll set it to 4,000.

130
00:06:59,770 --> 00:07:02,910
So it could be up to 4,000 characters.

131
00:07:02,910 --> 00:07:05,870
And if I write 4,000 characters in there,
that's how much space it will take.

132
00:07:05,870 --> 00:07:09,753
But if I write 2,000 characters in there,
it'll only consume 2,000.

133
00:07:09,753 --> 00:07:11,260
That's it, okay?

134
00:07:11,260 --> 00:07:14,810
So that's me kind of determining exactly
how much is gonna go in that field and

135
00:07:14,810 --> 00:07:16,810
how efficient my storage is.

136
00:07:16,810 --> 00:07:20,390
Other things, though, like the ID,
that's gonna be a number, right?

137
00:07:20,390 --> 00:07:23,620
I don't want text characters, I don't want
letters and things like that in there.

138
00:07:23,620 --> 00:07:27,380
So I might take this data type and
change it to an integer.

139
00:07:27,380 --> 00:07:29,220
So I'm gonna pick that right there, int.

140
00:07:29,220 --> 00:07:31,730
Right.
So that's gonna be an integer column, and

141
00:07:31,730 --> 00:07:35,020
price will be the same way,
that's gonna be an integer column.

142
00:07:36,610 --> 00:07:37,330
Whoops.

143
00:07:37,330 --> 00:07:38,770
If I can click on it.

144
00:07:42,832 --> 00:07:43,990
There we go.

145
00:07:43,990 --> 00:07:47,332
My taxable column,
that's gonna be Yes, No.

146
00:07:47,332 --> 00:07:48,911
It's an N character 10.

147
00:07:48,911 --> 00:07:52,750
I might drop that down to three.

148
00:07:52,750 --> 00:07:56,042
Three cuz yes is three letters,
no is two letters.

149
00:07:56,042 --> 00:07:58,220
So, nchar(3) would take care of that.

150
00:07:58,220 --> 00:07:59,667
Or if I'm doing true/false.

151
00:07:59,667 --> 00:08:04,630
I might wanna go nchar5 to be able to hold
true or false, based on what I'm doing.

152
00:08:04,630 --> 00:08:05,780
Or I could do integer.

153
00:08:05,780 --> 00:08:06,970
Zero is false, one is true.

154
00:08:06,970 --> 00:08:09,060
You know,
it's up to you how you wanna do that.

155
00:08:09,060 --> 00:08:11,520
So you'd pick the appropriate
data type for it.

156
00:08:11,520 --> 00:08:15,190
Now, for the most part as a DBA,
you worry about this, right?

157
00:08:15,190 --> 00:08:16,890
But as a system admin, you don't.

158
00:08:16,890 --> 00:08:20,170
The developer should be telling you
exactly what kind of data is going in

159
00:08:20,170 --> 00:08:21,550
which columns.

160
00:08:21,550 --> 00:08:24,560
But, if you're in one of those
environments where it's left up to you you

161
00:08:24,560 --> 00:08:27,390
may have to pick, and so we do have
some of the different choices here.

162
00:08:27,390 --> 00:08:29,950
There are some special
ones I want to point out.

163
00:08:29,950 --> 00:08:31,790
This n character 4,000.

164
00:08:31,790 --> 00:08:36,430
What if I want to store
more than 4,000 characters?

165
00:08:36,430 --> 00:08:38,240
Well that data type is not gonna work for
me.

166
00:08:38,240 --> 00:08:40,040
So I've gotta pick a different one.

167
00:08:40,040 --> 00:08:41,450
Well if I look at N character,

168
00:08:41,450 --> 00:08:45,210
that's it, there's no other variation
of N character that I can do.

169
00:08:45,210 --> 00:08:47,270
N variable character
had a value called max.

170
00:08:47,270 --> 00:08:48,978
What is that?

171
00:08:48,978 --> 00:08:53,760
Well, N variable character
max is a special data type.

172
00:08:53,760 --> 00:08:57,240
It's one that has an insanely large limit.

173
00:08:57,240 --> 00:08:58,740
If I remember right, it's four terabytes.

174
00:08:58,740 --> 00:08:59,570
But don't quote me on that.

175
00:08:59,570 --> 00:09:00,690
I might be wrong.

176
00:09:00,690 --> 00:09:02,250
It's massive, right?

177
00:09:02,250 --> 00:09:04,240
An insane amount of data.

178
00:09:04,240 --> 00:09:08,700
And when you have a cell that's in
a column that is nvarchar(MAX).

179
00:09:08,700 --> 00:09:12,480
You could store the entire text of
Moby Dick in there if you wanted, right?

180
00:09:12,480 --> 00:09:14,790
You could huge amounts of text in there.

181
00:09:14,790 --> 00:09:16,060
Very, very cool stuff.

182
00:09:16,060 --> 00:09:19,130
Well, what the database does, is it says
all right, this is gonna be big data.

183
00:09:19,130 --> 00:09:20,850
And I don't know how big it's gonna be.

184
00:09:20,850 --> 00:09:23,920
So, instead of storing it right
there with the other row data.

185
00:09:23,920 --> 00:09:25,960
We're going to move it to
the end of the database.

186
00:09:25,960 --> 00:09:29,270
It actually stores it in
a different place in the database.

187
00:09:29,270 --> 00:09:30,560
Because of the nature of the data.

188
00:09:30,560 --> 00:09:31,720
We don't know how big it's going to be.

189
00:09:31,720 --> 00:09:33,220
It could get vast.

190
00:09:33,220 --> 00:09:36,140
So, end variable character Max does that.

191
00:09:36,140 --> 00:09:37,520
There's another one called end text.

192
00:09:37,520 --> 00:09:39,640
It's in here somewhere.

193
00:09:39,640 --> 00:09:40,720
Right there, end text.

194
00:09:40,720 --> 00:09:41,700
It's another example.

195
00:09:41,700 --> 00:09:43,250
That's actually the old way of doing it.

196
00:09:43,250 --> 00:09:46,990
Where it would allow you to have huge
amounts of texts and you could stick that.

197
00:09:46,990 --> 00:09:48,790
It would go at the end of the database.

198
00:09:48,790 --> 00:09:51,230
There's another one called
binary that does the same thing.

199
00:09:51,230 --> 00:09:53,901
But instead of text Right here.

200
00:09:53,901 --> 00:09:56,490
Actually that one says binary 50.

201
00:09:56,490 --> 00:09:59,160
Oh that's right they've modified that one.

202
00:09:59,160 --> 00:10:03,320
Instead of binary 50,

450
00:22:41,430 --> 00:22:46,000

line will have a carriage return and

451
00:22:46,000 --> 00:22:47,070
a line feed.

452
00:22:47,070 --> 00:22:49,630
That's what the CRLF means.

453
00:22:49,630 --> 00:22:52,110
Those terms actually come
from the old typewriter days.

454
00:22:52,110 --> 00:22:55,950
On a typewriter,
when you reach the end of a line,

455
00:22:55,950 --> 00:22:59,740
you'd hear a bell and
then two things would happen.

456
00:22:59,740 --> 00:23:01,220
A carriage return,

457
00:23:01,220 --> 00:23:06,440
that would mean your typewriter head would
move all the way back to the left side.

458
00:23:06,440 --> 00:23:07,270
That's the carriage return.

459
00:23:07,270 --> 00:23:09,310
It's returning back to the left side.

460
00:23:09,310 --> 00:23:11,950
And then line feed,
the page would move up one line.

461
00:23:13,050 --> 00:23:16,640
So in Windows systems,
at the end of every line,

462
00:23:16,640 --> 00:23:19,280
there's a hidden character,
we don't see it but it's there.

463
00:23:19,280 --> 00:23:21,910
And it's a carriage return and
a line feed.

464
00:23:21,910 --> 00:23:23,800
But it's not like that in Unix systems.

00:23:23,800 --> 00:23:27,030

00:23:27,030 --> 00:23:29,460

00:23:30,960 --> 00:23:33,180

00:23:33,180 --> 00:23:36,160
At the end of the line, we just move to
the next one and the line feed does it.

So, if I want to bring that in,

That data is going into my database, and

00:33:33,070 --> 00:33:38,150
Now in SQL, when you reference an object,

00:33:38,150 --> 00:33:39,560
We haven't seen that in this show yet.

00:33:39,560 --> 00:33:42,660
I talk about it more in
the security episode, but

672
00:33:42,660 --> 00:33:45,330
the four-part name works like this.

673
00:33:45,330 --> 00:33:54,164
It's Servername.DatabaseName.Owner.Object,

674
00:33:54,164 --> 00:33:55,820
right?

675
00:33:55,820 --> 00:33:59,240
So when I reference
anything inside of SQL,

676
00:33:59,240 --> 00:34:04,140
this is the full name but
we don't use this notation very often.

677
00:34:04,140 --> 00:34:06,210
Because normally we're in the GUI.

00:34:06,210 --> 00:34:08,130
And when you're in the GUI,
when you're in here and

00:34:08,130 --> 00:34:11,720
you're working,
maybe you're doing a new query like this.

00:34:11,720 --> 00:34:14,510
Well, up here it's got
what database I'm on.

00:34:14,510 --> 00:34:18,370
It already knows the server because
I'm connected to it right here.

682
00:34:18,370 --> 00:34:21,230
It already knows the database
because it's right here and

00:34:21,230 --> 00:34:25,490
it will assume the owner as
it goes to work with things.

684
00:34:25,490 --> 00:34:27,230
So we normally leave all
that other stuff off.

685
00:34:27,230 --> 00:34:28,920
We don't see it very often.

00:34:28,920 --> 00:34:31,830
But when we're working with BCP,
we need to know it.

687
00:34:31,830 --> 00:34:33,440
It will make assumptions.

00:34:33,440 --> 00:34:36,860
It'll assume the server is
the server that we're on.

00:34:36,860 --> 00:34:38,710
But if you're running
BCP from your desktop,

00:34:38,710 --> 00:34:41,140
you'll need to specify the server.

00:34:41,140 --> 00:34:42,680
The database though we've gotta tell it.

00:34:42,680 --> 00:34:45,060
We've gotta tell it what
database we're working with.

We've gotta tell it the owner
of that database and

00:34:48,460 --> 00:34:52,070
we've gotta tell it the object in
the database we're copying the data to.

00:34:52,070 --> 00:34:54,510
So I wanna throw this stuff in.

00:34:54,510 --> 00:34:57,440
And I'm on the server, so

00:34:57,440 --> 00:35:01,300

00:35:01,300 --> 00:35:03,390
Now, I don't necessarily

00:35:03,390 --> 00:35:04,720
Right?
Who is the owner?

00:35:04,720 --> 00:35:06,870
Well it could have been changed, but

00:35:06,870 --> 00:35:11,900
if you haven't changed it there's
a default owner that almost everyone uses.

702
00:35:11,900 --> 00:35:16,230
And it's called dbo,
dbo stands for database owner.

703
00:35:16,230 --> 00:35:21,050
It's a generic ownership item and
we assign permissions around it.

704
00:35:21,050 --> 00:35:23,590
So dbo is actually kind of like a group.

705
00:35:23,590 --> 00:35:27,790
Instead of assigning ownership to me to,

00:35:27,790 --> 00:35:28,320
Right?

00:35:34,950 --> 00:35:39,630

00:35:39,630 --> 00:35:43,080

to reflect this new owner name.

00:35:43,080 --> 00:35:46,460
So it's generally bad
practice to change the owner.

712
00:35:46,460 --> 00:35:51,270
And that's why almost
everyone leaves it as dbo.

713
00:35:51,270 --> 00:35:53,690
And then you just put who you want

714
00:35:53,690 --> 00:35:56,410
And that way if you fire that employee,
you hire somebody else,

715
00:35:56,410 --> 00:35:59,270
you just put them into the group,
you don't have to rewrite your software.

716
00:35:59,270 --> 00:36:03,440
So you're almost certain to
always have dbo as the owner.

00:36:03,440 --> 00:36:06,820
There are exceptions, and

00:36:06,820 --> 00:36:09,150

In Microsoft SQL 2000 and

effectively the same thing,

00:36:24,890 --> 00:36:28,910

00:36:28,910 --> 00:36:31,500

00:37:11,310 --> 00:37:14,710

00:37:14,710 --> 00:37:16,110
It's a text file.

738
00:37:16,110 --> 00:37:19,400
It's not a binary file,
it's not some precompiled database,

00:37:19,400 --> 00:37:21,160
it's just a text file.

00:37:21,160 --> 00:37:23,435
And then, it's using a delimiter,

00:37:23,435 --> 00:37:28,225

00:37:28,225 --> 00:37:29,975

00:37:52,427 --> 00:37:54,047

00:37:57,177 --> 00:38:00,387

00:38:01,560 --> 00:38:04,630
Now, there's a lot of

00:38:04,630 --> 00:38:07,970

00:38:07,970 --> 00:38:09,050

00:38:09,050 --> 00:38:13,260

00:38:13,260 --> 00:38:17,870
So it's important to sanitize your

00:38:17,870 --> 00:38:21,950

We tell it the destination,

With bulk insert it's a query,

00:41:07,620 --> 00:41:11,800
it's a stored procedure on the server and

With bulk insert, we have to tell it

00:42:18,802 --> 00:42:26,370
WITH FORMATFILE, and

00:42:33,590 --> 00:42:34,751
Or it's usually a dat.

00:42:41,939 --> 00:42:42,960
There, like that.

So the bulk insert,

Just like BCP did.

So instead, you have to provide it with

00:43:05,200 --> 00:43:08,460

This is called the bulk insert,

The big difference between them,

Or maybe you don't have access to

00:43:51,690 --> 00:43:53,520

that SA account that's sitting there.

00:47:54,350 --> 00:47:56,910

there is something special

00:48:17,740 --> 00:48:20,590

00:48:20,590 --> 00:48:22,220

This one's confusing.

00:48:23,280 --> 00:48:26,110
A lot of people mix this

00:48:26,110 --> 00:48:29,740

00:48:55,485 --> 00:48:56,640
Public.

Public is a special one, right?

Everybody is a part of public.

00:50:32,260 --> 00:50:34,510

00:50:47,790 --> 00:50:49,920

00:50:49,920 --> 00:50:52,910

00:50:57,950 --> 00:51:02,270
There's db_denydatareader and

00:51:02,270 --> 00:51:04,810
This is where we can override

00:51:04,810 --> 00:51:06,827

00:51:06,827 --> 00:51:09,862

00:51:26,130 --> 00:51:28,650

00:51:36,690 --> 00:51:37,720

00:51:50,250 --> 00:51:52,550
There is db_backupoperator.

They can backup the database.

00:51:53,790 --> 00:51:55,270

Then we have public also.

Public being whatever access we want

00:56:33,640 --> 00:56:35,810

00:57:20,890 --> 00:57:24,220
Securables, that's saying

You got to give access to people so

00:57:27,740 --> 00:57:32,060
That's the whole point of being connected

00:57:32,060 --> 00:57:35,510

00:57:35,510 --> 00:57:40,110
you know, for db_general access.

1114
00:57:41,330 --> 00:57:45,830
And so I can create that role, so

I can start to manipulate

1116
00:57:49,200 --> 00:57:49,870
Alright.

The roles that are there

So, I've put them all in my notes with my

00:58:00,150 --> 00:58:00,930
Be familiar with those.

1121
00:58:02,030 --> 00:58:04,990
Remember which ones
are at the server level
