00:58:04,990 --> 00:58:07,220
versus which ones are at
the database level.

1123
00:58:07,220 --> 00:58:09,418
It's pretty easy because of the db_.

1124
00:58:09,418 --> 00:58:16,240
All right, now I mentioned schemas also.

1125
00:58:16,240 --> 00:58:20,770
Schemas are another way that
we can give people access.

1126
00:58:20,770 --> 00:58:23,760
When we looked at this database.

1127
00:58:23,760 --> 00:58:27,050
The database was attached to a scheme,
and really every object

1128
00:58:27,050 --> 00:58:29,690
inside of your database is
attached to a scheme of some sort.

1129
00:58:30,690 --> 00:58:34,570
In the old days,
every object had an owner, and

1130
00:58:34,570 --> 00:58:38,000
that owner was usually a user account,
alright.

1131
00:58:38,000 --> 00:58:42,560
And I mentioned this in another episode
when we reference an object in sequel.

1132
00:58:42,560 --> 00:58:46,450
There's a relative name, and
there's a fully qualified name.

1133
00:58:46,450 --> 00:58:50,570
If I take, for example,
here I am in the payroll database.

1134
00:58:51,660 --> 00:58:53,040
Sorry, let me clean up my mess here.

1135
00:58:53,040 --> 00:58:55,120
All right,
I'm in the payroll database, and

1136
00:58:55,120 --> 00:58:57,515
if I go into tables, I don't have
an don't have any tables, great.

1137
00:58:57,515 --> 00:59:00,035
Let me just create one, so

1138
00:59:00,035 --> 00:59:04,941
I'll whip up a table real quick and
I'll call this payroll.

1139
00:59:04,941 --> 00:59:09,392
All right, so in inside of this database,

1140
00:59:09,392 --> 00:59:13,937
I've got a table called payroll.

1141
00:59:13,937 --> 00:59:17,417
That table is an object
inside of the database.

1142
00:59:17,417 --> 00:59:19,887
Indexes are objects
inside of the databases.

1143
00:59:19,887 --> 00:59:22,157
Views are objects inside of the database.

1144
00:59:22,157 --> 00:59:25,957
The user accounts, these are all just
objects stored inside of the database.

1145
00:59:25,957 --> 00:59:30,077
And every object has a relative name and
a fully qualified name.

1146
00:59:30,077 --> 00:59:30,917
For this one.

1147
00:59:33,940 --> 00:59:37,140
So this is the sales table,
or the Payroll Table, right?

1148
00:59:37,140 --> 00:59:39,250
So this is the Payroll Table.

1149
00:59:40,520 --> 00:59:44,580
The Relative Name is Payroll.

1150
00:59:46,330 --> 00:59:47,730
That's it, just Payroll.

1151
00:59:47,730 --> 00:59:48,740
That's the relative name,

1152
00:59:48,740 --> 00:59:50,700
nothing to special there, but
the Fully Qualified Name is much longer.

1153
00:59:50,700 --> 00:59:52,770
The Fully Qualified Name

1154
00:59:57,090 --> 01:00:04,212
in this case is
WIN-SQL01.Payroll.dbo.Payroll.

1155
01:00:04,212 --> 01:00:05,582
All right?

1156
01:00:05,582 --> 01:00:13,080
I probably shouldn't have used the same,
we'll say this is in a different database.

1157
01:00:13,080 --> 01:00:13,700
Right?
Maybe this is in

1158
01:00:13,700 --> 01:00:15,120
the human resources database.

1159
01:00:17,310 --> 01:00:18,960
Or the accounting data.

1160
01:00:18,960 --> 01:00:24,070
So it would probably make
more sense to be accounting.

1161
01:00:24,070 --> 01:00:32,540
So what you're looking at here is
the Server.Database.Schema.Object.

1162
01:00:32,540 --> 01:00:35,100
That's what each of those
four entries reference.

1163
01:00:35,100 --> 01:00:38,210
That's the fully qualified name.

1164
01:00:38,210 --> 01:00:41,980
Now that is in SQL 2005 and newer.

1165
01:00:45,500 --> 01:00:50,455
[SOUND] In SQL 2000 and earlier,

1166
01:00:50,455 --> 01:00:55,245
my screen's gonna go crazy here,

1167
01:00:55,245 --> 01:00:59,880
that was a little bit different.

1168
01:00:59,880 --> 01:01:06,930
It was Server.Database.Owner.Object,
all right.

1169
01:01:06,930 --> 01:01:09,610
It used to be whoever owned it.

1170
01:01:09,610 --> 01:01:11,490
If I was the owner of
the payroll database,

1171
01:01:11,490 --> 01:01:14,140
my name was part of the qualified name.

1172
01:01:14,140 --> 01:01:17,870
So if I owned the payroll table,

1173
01:01:17,870 --> 01:01:23,672
Then it would've been
WIN-SQL01.HumanResources or

1174
01:01:23,672 --> 01:01:29,322
Accounting .DPezet.Payroll, all right?

1175
01:01:29,322 --> 01:01:32,110
Now that's fine, I'm the owner,
great, I'm part of the name.

1176
01:01:32,110 --> 01:01:35,460
But the problem was, if we wrote
all of our software to look for

1177
01:01:35,460 --> 01:01:38,960
that table using the full Fully
qualified name, and then I got fired or

1178
01:01:38,960 --> 01:01:42,770
I left the company or whatever, and
a new person came in as the owner.

1179
01:01:42,770 --> 01:01:46,020
Well, the owner changed all my software,

1180
01:01:46,020 --> 01:01:48,330
had to be recompiled to
point to this new location.

1181
01:01:48,330 --> 01:01:49,060
That was a problem.

1182
01:01:49,060 --> 01:01:50,720
It was a really big issue.

1183
01:01:50,720 --> 01:01:55,460
So, that change in SQL 2005, and what used
to be the Owner is now the Schema, and

1184
01:01:55,460 --> 01:01:59,246
the Schema is really just
like an alias for the Owner.

1185
01:01:59,246 --> 01:02:05,110
You make a Owner, you make a person own
the Schema and the Schema owns the Object.

1186
01:02:06,280 --> 01:02:09,910
So, this Schema Is not
a user account anymore.

1187
01:02:09,910 --> 01:02:13,500
It's more like a group or a container.

1188
01:02:13,500 --> 01:02:15,410
And it's the owner of the object and

1189
01:02:15,410 --> 01:02:17,930
now I can change who owns
the schema to change that.

1190
01:02:17,930 --> 01:02:22,670
Now that's pretty useful because we
can make somebody the owner of many

1191
01:02:22,670 --> 01:02:23,980
objects at once.

1192
01:02:23,980 --> 01:02:25,010
Let me show you an example.

1193
01:02:26,240 --> 01:02:32,450
In my notes, I put out a little example
here, of some items in a database.

1194
01:02:32,450 --> 01:02:34,830
Maybe the database is called company.

1195
01:02:34,830 --> 01:02:39,880
And then the schemas here are accounting,
DBO, HR.

1196
01:02:39,880 --> 01:02:40,920
Then the objects.

1197
01:02:40,920 --> 01:02:44,120
There's an orders table,
an expenses table, and so on.

1198
01:02:44,120 --> 01:02:45,470
All of these are in the same database.

1199
01:02:45,470 --> 01:02:48,361
Now, notice how I only
put three values here.

1200
01:02:48,361 --> 01:02:49,860
I didn't put the server name.

1201
01:02:49,860 --> 01:02:53,530
If you leave something off, if you leave
the server name off, it assumes that

1202
01:02:53,530 --> 01:02:56,150
you're talking about the server that
you're running this command from.

1203
01:02:56,150 --> 01:02:59,330
If you leave the database name off,
it assumes you're running

1204
01:02:59,330 --> 01:03:01,920
from the database that you're
connected to currently.

1205
01:03:01,920 --> 01:03:02,690
All right.

1206
01:03:02,690 --> 01:03:07,070
But the schema, if you leave that off,
it assumes it's your default schema.

1207
01:03:07,070 --> 01:03:08,890
Which we'll see how to
set that in a minute.

1208
01:03:08,890 --> 01:03:11,790
But, otherwise, you have to manually
put in the schema and the object name.

1209
01:03:11,790 --> 01:03:14,350
The object name is really
the only one you have to provide.

1210
01:03:14,350 --> 01:03:17,500
You have to provide an object name, or
you don't know what you're working with.

1211
01:03:17,500 --> 01:03:19,796
Right.
So I left the server name off on here.

1212
01:03:19,796 --> 01:03:24,870
It's just going to assume I'm on my local
server if I hire a new accountant and

1213
01:03:24,870 --> 01:03:29,200
I want that accountant to have full
control of the accounting tables, and

1214
01:03:29,200 --> 01:03:30,360
there's 50 accounting tables.

1215
01:03:31,380 --> 01:03:34,430
If I create an accounting schema, and

1216
01:03:34,430 --> 01:03:38,610
the accounting schema owns
all the accounting tables.

1217
01:03:38,610 --> 01:03:40,910
All I have to do is take
that new accountant, and

1218
01:03:40,910 --> 01:03:44,600
make them the owner of
the Accounting schema.

1219
01:03:44,600 --> 01:03:47,930
And when that happens,
they own Accounting, and

1220
01:03:47,930 --> 01:03:49,870
Accounting owns these tables.

1221
01:03:49,870 --> 01:03:52,220
So now, that person owns all these tables.

1222
01:03:52,220 --> 01:03:53,458
It makes life a lot easier.

1223
01:03:53,458 --> 01:03:56,381
And I can change that
owner out whenever I want,

1224
01:03:56,381 --> 01:03:58,875
without having to rewrite my software.

1225
01:03:58,875 --> 01:04:02,610
So, think of a schema as like a, an alias.

1226
01:04:02,610 --> 01:04:05,167
All right?
It's really easy to think it as a group.

1227
01:04:05,167 --> 01:04:08,410
Put a person in this schema group or
whatever, and then they have the access.

1228
01:04:08,410 --> 01:04:13,740
But the problem is, a user can
only be in one schema at a time.

1229
01:04:13,740 --> 01:04:16,350
If I attach a schema to a particular user,
that's it.

1230
01:04:16,350 --> 01:04:17,020
They're in it.

1231
01:04:17,020 --> 01:04:18,750
Right?
They're in that place.

1232
01:04:18,750 --> 01:04:21,530
So it's a lot different than groups,

1233
01:04:21,530 --> 01:04:24,950
where you can be in a ton of different
groups at once, and off you go.

1234
01:04:24,950 --> 01:04:28,010
Also, Schema is really
just owned by one person.

1235
01:04:28,010 --> 01:04:31,390
We could use a Windows group to get around
that, have a Windows group own the Schema

1236
01:04:31,390 --> 01:04:33,750
and then whoever's in that Windows
group would have the access.

1237
01:04:33,750 --> 01:04:36,100
But it's really designed
to be owned by one person.

1238
01:04:36,100 --> 01:04:37,400
So we'd have to be
a little bit careful with

1239
01:04:39,040 --> 01:04:42,120
that because the old way was such a mess.

1240
01:04:42,120 --> 01:04:45,570
The old way, where this was
an individual user, was such a mess

1241
01:04:45,570 --> 01:04:50,660
that most developers got in the habit
of just leaving it at the default.

1242
01:04:50,660 --> 01:04:58,449
The default owner [SOUND]
is an account called DBO.

1243
01:04:58,449 --> 01:05:01,440
And it's not really an account at all,
it's just a group.

1244
01:05:01,440 --> 01:05:03,800
It's called DBO,
which stands for Database Owner.

1245
01:05:03,800 --> 01:05:08,160
And most SQL developers have gotten in
the habit of just leaving it that way.

1246
01:05:08,160 --> 01:05:12,010
Notice, when I created that payroll table
a minute ago, see how it's DBO.payroll.

1247
01:05:12,010 --> 01:05:15,120
So, DBO owns the payroll table.

1248
01:05:15,120 --> 01:05:16,191
All right?

1249
01:05:16,191 --> 01:05:21,280
Now, the sysadmin group DBO role.

1250
01:05:21,280 --> 01:05:24,850
And so anybody I put in the system
admins group will own DBO,

1251
01:05:24,850 --> 01:05:26,660
which in turn owns payroll,
they'll own that table.

1252
01:05:26,660 --> 01:05:28,720
They'll have access to
do whatever they want.

1253
01:05:28,720 --> 01:05:32,120
and so most developers out there will
tell you to just leave it at DBO.

1254
01:05:32,120 --> 01:05:32,770
But you do not have to.

1255
01:05:32,770 --> 01:05:35,800
You can use it to really
leverage permissions if you want,

1256
01:05:35,800 --> 01:05:38,680
you just need to create
your own schemas to do it.

1257
01:05:38,680 --> 01:05:40,190
So if we take,

1258
01:05:40,190 --> 01:05:43,420
lets go up to my Human Resource database

01:17:28,310 --> 01:17:30,560
So that's a very common scenario.

So the application needs

1490
01:17:42,930 --> 01:17:46,630

1491
01:17:46,630 --> 01:17:50,470
That will ensure that only that

01:17:50,470 --> 01:17:53,690
You might have further authentication for

01:17:53,690 --> 01:17:58,550

will use certificates to show that it's

01:17:58,550 --> 01:18:02,350

You can use it, not just for

01:18:03,820 --> 01:18:06,700

01:18:06,700 --> 01:18:11,580

a transport layer security tunnel between

1498
01:18:11,580 --> 01:18:15,480

somebody is intercepting traffic they'll

01:18:15,480 --> 01:18:20,720

01:20:10,740 --> 01:20:12,370
They go, all right,
well I got an error, let me retry it.

1539
01:20:12,370 --> 01:20:14,480
Pretty straight forward.

1540
01:20:14,480 --> 01:20:18,030
But for an application,
when it reaches out to that server,

1541
01:20:18,030 --> 01:20:21,250
it might be doing something very
critical like doing a funds transfer,

1542
01:20:21,250 --> 01:20:24,170

1543
01:20:24,170 --> 01:20:27,390
We need to ensure that that
communication gets through.

1544
01:20:27,390 --> 01:20:31,590
And if the sequel database is offline or
if it's busy, we don't care.

1545
01:20:31,590 --> 01:20:35,290
We still want that transmission to
get there, and to be queued up,

1546
01:20:35,290 --> 01:20:39,690
sitting there, ready to be applied as soon
as the database becomes healthy again.

1547
01:20:39,690 --> 01:20:42,660
Those are called reliable transactions.

1548
01:20:42,660 --> 01:20:43,920
With an application,

1549
01:20:43,920 --> 01:20:47,860
you want to ensure that your transactions
always execute successfully.

1550
01:20:47,860 --> 01:20:50,080
And the service broker allows that.

1551
01:20:50,080 --> 01:20:53,970
What the service broker does,
is it sits in between your program, and

1552
01:20:53,970 --> 01:20:55,110
the data base.

1553
01:20:55,110 --> 01:20:58,760
And when your program wants to add
something to the data base, instead of

1554
01:20:58,760 --> 01:21:01,965
reaching out to the data base directly
it reaches out to the service broker.

1555
01:21:01,965 --> 01:21:07,055
And the service broker gathers the data
and queues it up, it holds it.

1556
01:21:07,055 --> 01:21:10,245
And then it reaches out to the database
and it goes to make the change.

1557
01:21:10,245 --> 01:21:15,220
If the database is offline, the service
broker just holds onto the change,

1558
01:21:15,220 --> 01:21:20,010
holds it and waits, and when the database
becomes healthy it then applies it.

1559
01:21:20,010 --> 01:21:22,350
That's different than a transaction log,
right?

1560
01:21:22,350 --> 01:21:25,340
If a transaction log goes to apply
something to the database and the database

1561
01:21:25,340 --> 01:21:29,260
is offline, the transaction log will just
throw the change away, it didn't happen.

1562
01:21:29,260 --> 01:21:31,350
All right, but the service broker won't.

1563
01:21:31,350 --> 01:21:36,490
It will hold on to things, and
that ensures reliable transmissions.

1564
01:21:36,490 --> 01:21:39,340
You can also have the service broker
where it'll queue up things throughout

1565
01:21:39,340 --> 01:21:42,110

01:21:47,060 --> 01:21:50,530

1569
01:21:50,530 --> 01:21:55,940

1570
01:21:55,940 --> 01:22:00,230

show up on your account until tomorrow,

1571
01:22:00,230 --> 01:22:02,070
all right, until 8:00 AM the next day.

1572
01:22:02,070 --> 01:22:04,560
Well, what's happened to that transaction?

1573
01:22:04,560 --> 01:22:08,150
They're putting it in the system, but
it doesn't apply to your account.

1574
01:22:08,150 --> 01:22:10,790
What's happening is,
they've got a service broker.

1575
01:22:10,790 --> 01:22:12,280
You receive the transaction.

1576
01:22:12,280 --> 01:22:14,618
Yes, they got that deposit
you want to make, but

1577
01:22:14,618 --> 01:22:18,558
it's sitting in a queue in the service
broker, and the next morning at 8:00 AM

1578
01:22:18,558 --> 01:22:21,435
the service broker kicks in and
applies all those changes.

1579
01:22:21,435 --> 01:22:23,200
Posts all those deposits to the accounts.

1580
01:22:23,200 --> 01:22:24,755
And all of a sudden, you're good to go.

1581
01:22:24,755 --> 01:22:29,890
So throughout the day, from 8:00 AM to
3:00 PM they're applying those right away.

1582
01:22:29,890 --> 01:22:33,180
And then at 3 PM,
the service broker goes into hold mode.

1583
01:22:33,180 --> 01:22:34,610
And it just holds the transaction.

1584
01:22:34,610 --> 01:22:36,020
That's the kind of thing it does.

1585
01:22:36,020 --> 01:22:37,720
Your transaction is not lost.

1586
01:22:37,720 --> 01:22:39,660
It's just sitting there waiting for
you, all right.

1587
01:22:39,660 --> 01:22:42,200
It's not something an end
user is ever gonna do.

This is something a program would do.

01:14:38,350 --> 01:14:42,140

says when I make a change on server one,

1489
01:14:42,140 --> 01:14:45,950

send the change to server two.

1490
01:14:45,950 --> 01:14:47,310

01:14:54,580 --> 01:14:59,100

1495

01:15:29,510 --> 01:15:32,310

01:15:48,340 --> 01:15:51,650

1520
01:16:05,410 --> 01:16:07,660

01:16:07,660 --> 01:16:09,560
Just because it's taking

01:16:09,560 --> 01:16:12,940
it's further away on the network,

to a second server,

With mirroring, I can go and lock step.

01:20:13,340 --> 01:20:13,958

01:20:16,480 --> 01:20:20,083

01:20:20,083 --> 01:20:21,459
As long as there's changes happening,

01:20:21,459 --> 01:20:23,042

01:20:23,042 --> 01:20:24,500

01:20:24,500 --> 01:20:27,167

log shipping over mirroring?

01:20:27,167 --> 01:20:30,341

with transaction log shipping,

1624
01:20:30,341 --> 01:20:33,800

1625
01:20:33,800 --> 01:20:37,025
So, you can replicate your database not

01:20:37,025 --> 01:20:38,500
50 locations.

1627
01:20:38,500 --> 01:20:41,760
So, you can have it in several
different places which gives you

1628
01:20:41,760 --> 01:20:43,140
a lot of redundancy.

1629
01:20:43,140 --> 01:20:45,960
In fact,
the most common deployment of this

1630
01:20:45,960 --> 01:20:50,030

01:20:50,030 --> 01:20:54,230

1632
01:20:54,230 --> 01:20:57,810

1633
01:20:57,810 --> 01:21:01,870
So, it's replicated right there,

1634
01:21:01,870 --> 01:21:05,720
But then you use transaction log shipping
to send the changes to your disaster

1635
01:21:05,720 --> 01:21:08,290

to another facility somewhere else.

1636
01:21:08,290 --> 01:21:12,950
Now you're sending your stuff offsite,

01:21:12,950 --> 01:21:18,690

01:21:34,730 --> 01:21:38,240

01:21:38,240 --> 01:21:40,266

if you're like me and
you're super impatient,

2065
01:41:52,562 --> 01:41:55,909
what you can do is you can run
ALTER DATABASE and the name.

2066
01:41:59,952 --> 01:42:02,174
So, ALTER DATABASE, HumanResources for me.

2067
01:42:02,174 --> 01:42:10,170
SET SINGLE_USER WITH ROLLBACK IMMEDIATE.

2068
01:42:10,170 --> 01:42:10,790
All right.

2069
01:42:10,790 --> 01:42:13,220
What that does is it puts
the database in single user mode, so

2070
01:42:13,220 --> 01:42:14,570
nobody else can mess with it.

2071
01:42:14,570 --> 01:42:17,590
In other words,
stop doing transaction log updates to it.

2072
01:42:17,590 --> 01:42:18,870
All right, stop messing with it.

2073
01:42:18,870 --> 01:42:20,290
I need to bring it online.

2074
01:42:20,290 --> 01:42:21,940
And then with ROLLBACK IMMEDIATE,

2075
01:42:21,940 --> 01:42:25,610
that says if any transactions were
in process, just roll them back.

2076
01:42:25,610 --> 01:42:27,240
Don't try and finish them,
just roll them back.

2077
01:42:27,240 --> 01:42:28,200
Undo them.

2078
01:42:28,200 --> 01:42:30,330
Give me this database so
I can work with it.

2079
01:42:30,330 --> 01:42:33,450
If you run that,
then you can turn around, and

2080
01:42:33,450 --> 01:42:38,570
run restore database human resources with
recovery, and it will bring it online.

2081
01:42:38,570 --> 01:42:42,780
Hopefully, this command works for you
the first time, or you just wait a minute,

2082
01:42:42,780 --> 01:42:44,130
run it again and then it works.

2083
01:42:44,130 --> 01:42:46,880
But if it's still holding and
you're getting impatient, because there's

2084
01:42:46,880 --> 01:42:50,210
a failure and you need to get rolling,
you run the second command right here.

2085
01:42:50,210 --> 01:42:53,510
Flip it into single user mode, that'll
force it to where you can get in and

2086
01:42:53,510 --> 01:42:57,650
work with it and then you do that
restore and you're back in business.

2087
01:42:57,650 --> 01:43:02,530
But I lucked out, it worked out just fine
for me, so if I refresh my database list,

2088
01:43:03,560 --> 01:43:06,300
I can see there's my human
resources database and

2089
01:43:06,300 --> 01:43:09,119
let's see if my records made it over
right, I changed some phone numbers.

2090
01:43:10,650 --> 01:43:14,240
So if I go in here and I look,
oh, I didn't wait long enough.

2091
01:43:14,240 --> 01:43:16,390
See how my Indigo Saunders,

2092
01:43:16,390 --> 01:43:20,820
that phone number changed but Kyla Heath,
she still has her old number.

2093
01:43:20,820 --> 01:43:22,200
That means I didn't wait long enough,

2094
01:43:22,200 --> 01:43:26,360
my transaction logs hadn't shipped
over yet that contained that change.

2095
01:43:26,360 --> 01:43:27,550
So I lost some data.

2096
01:43:27,550 --> 01:43:31,300
I didn't lose more than five minutes
of data, but I did lose data.

2097
01:43:31,300 --> 01:43:34,150
That's one of the negatives
of transaction log shipping.

2098
01:43:34,150 --> 01:43:39,230
The schedule you pick determines
how much data you can lose, so

2099
01:43:39,230 --> 01:43:41,590
you gotta be careful with that.

2100
01:43:41,590 --> 01:43:44,170
But in this scenario,
this database is online on.

2101
01:43:44,170 --> 01:43:47,480
I just need to point my end
users to this database, and

2102
01:43:47,480 --> 01:43:48,930
now they're back in the system.

2103
01:43:48,930 --> 01:43:52,480
And the SQL native client doesn't
automatically pick this one up, so

2104
01:43:52,480 --> 01:43:54,350
everybody's gotta be redirected.

2105
01:43:54,350 --> 01:43:57,600
You could do it through DNS names, or
you could just bake it into your software.

2106
01:43:57,600 --> 01:44:00,460
Tell your software to connect to this
server first and if that server's

2107
01:44:00,460 --> 01:44:02,980
not available, try and connect to this
one, or this one, or this one, and

2108
01:44:02,980 --> 01:44:05,690
set all your various end points in
there for it to try and connect to.

2109
01:44:06,700 --> 01:44:08,370
Doesn't take that much to
bring it active though,

2110
01:44:08,370 --> 01:44:11,090
you can automate that with scripts or
whatever if you want.

2111
01:44:11,090 --> 01:44:12,910
But, I usually manually do it.

2112
01:44:12,910 --> 01:44:14,640
If there's a giant failure, you go and

2113
01:44:14,640 --> 01:44:17,140
wake the database up and
it's ready to rock.

2114
01:44:18,340 --> 01:44:23,180
Alright, so we gotta take a look at SQL
clustering, then we did mirroring and

2115
01:44:23,180 --> 01:44:25,240
lastly we did transaction log shipping.

2116
01:44:25,240 --> 01:44:27,990
Three different ways that we can
make our database redundant and

2117
01:44:27,990 --> 01:44:31,340
provide people access
even in times of failure.

2118
01:44:31,340 --> 01:44:32,910
None of them were
particularly hard to set up.

2119
01:44:32,910 --> 01:44:34,070
They all had their little quirks.

2120
01:44:34,070 --> 01:44:35,810
Little problems that happened, but for

2121
01:44:35,810 --> 01:44:39,310
the most part, we restore it, get it back
in action, and you're ready to rock.

2122
01:44:40,440 --> 01:44:42,900
All right.
Well, let me remind you guys.

2123
01:44:42,900 --> 01:44:46,110
If you have questions on any of this,
feel free ask.

2124
01:44:46,110 --> 01:44:48,520
Live during the show you
can go to itpro.tv/live.

2125
01:44:48,520 --> 01:44:50,320
Post your questions right there.

2126
01:44:50,320 --> 01:44:52,420
You'll see the chat room
right beneath the video.

2127
01:44:52,420 --> 01:44:55,940
If you have questions after the show,
use our Q&A forums.

2128
01:44:55,940 --> 01:44:57,610
At the top of each page,
you'll see a link that says Q&A,

2129
01:44:57,610 --> 01:44:59,460
it'll take you into the forums.

2130
01:44:59,460 --> 01:45:00,370
Post your questions there.

2131
01:45:00,370 --> 01:45:01,790
We monitor and answer.

2132
01:45:01,790 --> 01:45:04,650
We wanna make sure you guys have
the information you need to be successful.

2133
01:45:05,815 --> 01:45:09,125
All right well I hope you guys enjoyed
the show, signing off for ITProTV.

2134
01:45:09,125 --> 01:45:12,384
I'm Don Pezet and
I will see you next time.

2135
01:45:12,384 --> 01:45:17,646
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Don demonstrates assorted tools and techniques for monitoring your SQL server to ensure health and peak performance.
episodes.title: Monitoring SQL Server
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,347 --> 00:00:37,000
All right, good morning, good afternoon,
and good evening, and welcome back.

3
00:00:37,000 --> 00:00:40,640
To another episode of ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

4
00:00:40,640 --> 00:00:43,880
Back again with another
episode of Microsoft SQL.

5
00:00:43,880 --> 00:00:47,065
Now we have been on a roller
coaster ride of adventure.

6
00:00:47,065 --> 00:00:51,050
[LAUGH] As we've gone through learning
about setting up our database servers,

7
00:00:51,050 --> 00:00:55,343
and doing our redundancy and other types
of optimizations and things like that.

8
00:00:55,343 --> 00:00:59,330
Now we're gonna switch gears
into just regular operation.

9
00:00:59,330 --> 00:01:01,970
After you spend all of that time
getting your server set up,

10
00:01:01,970 --> 00:01:05,670
getting everything put just the way you
wanted it, optimizing your hard drives,

11
00:01:05,670 --> 00:01:09,343
and setting it loose to your developers,
well your job doesn't end.

12
00:01:09,343 --> 00:01:13,525
Right?
Now, you get the routine maintenance task.

13
00:01:13,525 --> 00:01:15,490
Right?
Just keeping the server up and

14
00:01:15,490 --> 00:01:16,470
operational.

15
00:01:16,470 --> 00:01:20,160
So, in this episode we're going to focus
on How to monitor your SQL server.

16
00:01:20,160 --> 00:01:24,520
How to look at it and see how performance
is doing, how well it's running and

17
00:01:24,520 --> 00:01:26,890
whether or not we need to take actions.

18
00:01:26,890 --> 00:01:30,580
Way back, in the beginning of the series
we talked about optimizing your hard disks

19
00:01:30,580 --> 00:01:35,190
and how you could do RAID 5, but RAID 10
will get you a better performance profile.

20
00:01:35,190 --> 00:01:38,510
Different solutions like that
really improve performance.

21
00:01:38,510 --> 00:01:40,240
But you may not need that.

22
00:01:40,240 --> 00:01:43,700
You may have a very low-utilization
database where you don't need to spend

23
00:01:43,700 --> 00:01:48,630
a ton of money on hardware, because the
database just isn't very resource hungry.

24
00:01:48,630 --> 00:01:49,560
Well, how do we know?

25
00:01:49,560 --> 00:01:52,045
How do we know how
resource-hungry our database is?

26
00:01:52,045 --> 00:01:54,085
Well, it really depends.

27
00:01:54,085 --> 00:01:58,180
[LAUGH] Unfortunately,
there's no one size fits all answer.

28
00:01:58,180 --> 00:02:01,670
Everybody's database is a little bit
different and how we do our queries,

29
00:02:01,670 --> 00:02:03,270
those all make changes.

30
00:02:03,270 --> 00:02:05,030
Right?
Make it difficult to just

31
00:02:05,030 --> 00:02:06,550
have a one size fits all.

32
00:02:06,550 --> 00:02:10,290
If it was, if there was a one solution
works for everybody type environment,

33
00:02:10,290 --> 00:02:13,940
we wouldn't have to worry about indexes,
Microsoft would create the indexes for us.

34
00:02:13,940 --> 00:02:14,550
Right?
But

35
00:02:14,550 --> 00:02:18,400
instead we have tools like the database
engine tuning adviser, where we can

36
00:02:18,400 --> 00:02:22,400
feed it data and it makes decisions
based off of the data that we give it.

37
00:02:22,400 --> 00:02:26,570
Knowing that our use case scenario may
be unique across the entire planet.

38
00:02:26,570 --> 00:02:29,500
There may not be a single other company
out there that does work the way that we

39
00:02:29,500 --> 00:02:31,992
do it, so it's got to customize it for us.

40
00:02:31,992 --> 00:02:32,830
All right.

41
00:02:32,830 --> 00:02:34,960
So we need to watch our server.

42
00:02:34,960 --> 00:02:38,162
And know when it's time to go in and
make those changes.

43
00:02:38,162 --> 00:02:39,550
All right.

44
00:02:39,550 --> 00:02:41,020
Well, let's talk about one scenario first.

45
00:02:41,020 --> 00:02:43,170
This is the one that I
get asked most commonly.

46
00:02:43,170 --> 00:02:47,750
Don, I'm about to set up a database
server, what hardware do I need?

47
00:02:47,750 --> 00:02:48,930
How many CPUs do I need?

48
00:02:48,930 --> 00:02:51,670
What disk structure,
what should I start out with?

49
00:02:51,670 --> 00:02:53,330
Right?
That's a real tough one.

50
00:02:53,330 --> 00:02:55,000
Right?
It's a tough one because you don't have

51
00:02:55,000 --> 00:02:56,130
a database in production yet.

52
00:02:56,130 --> 00:02:58,180
You don't have any metrics to measure of.

53
00:02:58,180 --> 00:03:00,130
This is something that is brand new.

54
00:03:00,130 --> 00:03:05,490
So how do you spec out a server before
you even know what you're going to need.

55
00:03:05,490 --> 00:03:06,170
All right?

56
00:03:06,170 --> 00:03:08,480
Well, Microsoft has a neat little utility.

57
00:03:08,480 --> 00:03:11,440
This used to be a utility you had
to go to Microsoft and download but

58
00:03:11,440 --> 00:03:15,570
in the last few versions of SQL,
it's been baked into the product, and

59
00:03:15,570 --> 00:03:18,640
it's called the SQL IO Simulator.

60
00:03:18,640 --> 00:03:23,630
The SQL Input Output Simulator.

61
00:03:23,630 --> 00:03:27,450
What it does, is it allows you to
bring up like a test environment for

62
00:03:27,450 --> 00:03:31,190
your database, and
run the IO Simulator on it,

63
00:03:31,190 --> 00:03:34,820
providing it a work load that's similar
to what you're gonna need in production.

64
00:03:34,820 --> 00:03:38,030
And then it'll run it again through
whatever machine you're on right then and

65
00:03:38,030 --> 00:03:40,540
tell you whether that machine
can do that job or not.

66
00:03:40,540 --> 00:03:42,430
And if the machine can do the job, great.

67
00:03:42,430 --> 00:03:45,740
But if it can't, it tells you
the specs that you're going to need,

68
00:03:45,740 --> 00:03:49,060
exactly how much disk IO activity
you're gonna be generating.

69
00:03:49,060 --> 00:03:52,230
It's a really cool utility
because you might be one person.

70
00:03:52,230 --> 00:03:57,440
But the SQLIO simulator can generate
traffic that is reflective of tons and

71
00:03:57,440 --> 00:03:59,740
tons of people, hundreds,
thousands of users.

72
00:03:59,740 --> 00:04:04,860
Now, you'll see people talk about
the SQLIO simulator on the Internet, and

73
00:04:04,860 --> 00:04:07,190
some of them have it right
some of them have it wrong.

74
00:04:07,190 --> 00:04:10,390
It's really designed to simulate IO.

75
00:04:10,390 --> 00:04:11,810
Right?
That's the name.

76
00:04:11,810 --> 00:04:15,920
And it's used for specking out the proper
server to use in your environment.

77
00:04:15,920 --> 00:04:18,480
You'll hear people out there who
say to use it for stress testing.

78
00:04:18,480 --> 00:04:20,520
This is a great way to
stress test your server.

79
00:04:20,520 --> 00:04:21,630
Well, it doesn't do that.

80
00:04:21,630 --> 00:04:23,520
All right?
It doesn't stress test.

81
00:04:23,520 --> 00:04:27,810
A stress test will basically find
out what your server is capable of.

82
00:04:27,810 --> 00:04:31,900
It'll slowly increase it's load until
it reaches the limit of your server,

83
00:04:31,900 --> 00:04:34,540
then it'll tell you what your
server's maximum capabilities are.

84
00:04:34,540 --> 00:04:35,320
Right?

85
00:04:35,320 --> 00:04:37,170
The SQLIOSim doesn't do that.

86
00:04:37,170 --> 00:04:38,610
You give it a certain amount of load and

87
00:04:38,610 --> 00:04:41,050
either your server performs it or
it doesn't.

88
00:04:41,050 --> 00:04:44,670
It doesn't find the sweet spot,
it doesn't find that tipping point.

89
00:04:44,670 --> 00:04:47,380
There's a lot of third party
utilities out there that do that.

90
00:04:47,380 --> 00:04:51,790
But what the SQLIOSim does is it let's
you specify a level of activity and

91
00:04:51,790 --> 00:04:54,500
then the server will react in kind.

92
00:04:54,500 --> 00:04:58,800
Now, it is built into SQL, so it's not
something I have to install, but in

93
00:04:58,800 --> 00:05:03,300
the episode notes for this show, I'm gonna
put the link here to Microsoft's page.

94
00:05:03,300 --> 00:05:07,840
Even though we don't need to download it
anymore, it's just part of the system.

95
00:05:07,840 --> 00:05:10,950
It's still a good idea to
go to Microsoft's site and

96
00:05:10,950 --> 00:05:13,040
check out some information
on how to use it.

97
00:05:13,040 --> 00:05:15,042
The product is very complex.

98
00:05:15,042 --> 00:05:18,520
I'm gonna show you the quickest,
easiest way to run it.

99
00:05:18,520 --> 00:05:21,000
But it's also one of the least effective.

100
00:05:21,000 --> 00:05:24,600
The quickest, easiest way is to just run
the simulator and point it at your server.

101
00:05:24,600 --> 00:05:30,200
And it's gonna reach in there and generate
a bunch of traffic for a generic data set.

102
00:05:30,200 --> 00:05:32,040
That doesn't reflect your company at all.

103
00:05:32,040 --> 00:05:35,820
It reflects some general idea
that somebody at Microsoft had.

104
00:05:35,820 --> 00:05:38,550
Your use case scenario may
be completely different.

105
00:05:38,550 --> 00:05:42,120
So for the SQLIOSim to be truly useful,

106
00:05:42,120 --> 00:05:45,430
you need to create a custom workload for
it.

107
00:05:45,430 --> 00:05:49,030
And so when you run it, you'll see here
in the syntax, or here's the downloads.

108
00:05:49,030 --> 00:05:52,160
If you're running an older version of
SQL you can download a newer versions.

109
00:05:52,160 --> 00:05:53,090
You don't need it.

110
00:05:53,090 --> 00:05:56,160
But, so
there's all the different downloads.

111
00:05:56,160 --> 00:05:59,040
And then it goes on to talk about
the command line parameters, and

112
00:05:59,040 --> 00:06:02,960
this is the important one right here,
-cfg and a file.

113
00:06:02,960 --> 00:06:08,020
You can provide a configuration file to it
that'll tell it exactly what test to run,

114
00:06:08,020 --> 00:06:09,590
how much load to generate.

115
00:06:09,590 --> 00:06:13,740
And what you're doing is you're saying,
we anticipate having this many users, and

116
00:06:13,740 --> 00:06:16,640
we anticipate them running these types
of queries that are gonna generate this

117
00:06:16,640 --> 00:06:17,240
amount of disk IO.

118
00:06:18,310 --> 00:06:19,490
Can my server handle it.

119
00:06:19,490 --> 00:06:20,080
Right?

120
00:06:20,080 --> 00:06:23,380
Or is this server not enough and
I need to step up to do something more.

121
00:06:23,380 --> 00:06:23,880
Right?

122
00:06:23,880 --> 00:06:27,720
And you run the test and it'll tell you
whether your current server can do it, or

123
00:06:27,720 --> 00:06:29,450
whether you need to bump up to a new one.

124
00:06:29,450 --> 00:06:32,030
So, it is a great way to
spec out that new system.

125
00:06:32,030 --> 00:06:35,990
All right, but that configuration file
is kind of complex to write and so

126
00:06:35,990 --> 00:06:38,710
they've got all
the documentation right here.

127
00:06:38,710 --> 00:06:40,520
It's basically an XML document, and

128
00:06:40,520 --> 00:06:45,540
you specify all the information that
is gonna be reflective of your server.

129
00:06:45,540 --> 00:06:48,530
How long your IOs are gonna be,
whether you're doing write through,

130
00:06:48,530 --> 00:06:52,430
all that other stuff to be able to go
in and craft that configuration file.

131
00:06:52,430 --> 00:06:56,240
Now I can't tell you what to put there
because I don't know your use case

132
00:06:56,240 --> 00:06:59,360
scenario, I don't know what your
database is going to be like.

133
00:06:59,360 --> 00:07:02,630
So, if you're just trying to get
arbitrary numbers together you can run it

134
00:07:02,630 --> 00:07:04,030
with its generic config file.

135
00:07:04,030 --> 00:07:07,960
But it's not gonna be as effective
as if you had configured it just for

136
00:07:07,960 --> 00:07:08,882
your environment.

137
00:07:08,882 --> 00:07:11,380
All right?
Let me show you how it works.

138
00:07:11,380 --> 00:07:18,180
So here is my SQL server and, sorry,
let me get out of all this junk here.

139
00:07:18,180 --> 00:07:20,590
And I'll just get into my
SQL Management Studio.

140
00:07:20,590 --> 00:07:22,400
This is the one that we've
been using all-show long.

141
00:07:22,400 --> 00:07:24,480
This is WINSQL01.

142
00:07:24,480 --> 00:07:25,810
It's already running SQL.

143
00:07:25,810 --> 00:07:26,820
It's up and happy.

144
00:07:26,820 --> 00:07:30,420
To run the SQLIOSim,
you do already have to be running SQL.

145
00:07:30,420 --> 00:07:33,610
I've only got one database on here,
my human resources database.

146
00:07:33,610 --> 00:07:36,530
And I've disabled all the transaction
log shipping and mirroring and

147
00:07:36,530 --> 00:07:38,420
all that other stuff we set
up in previous episodes.

148
00:07:38,420 --> 00:07:39,420
That's all gone.

149
00:07:39,420 --> 00:07:41,520
So it's just a real simple database.

150
00:07:41,520 --> 00:07:43,070
The server is sitting here idle,

151
00:07:43,070 --> 00:07:45,580
you might have noticed my task
manager when I first fired this up.

152
00:07:46,860 --> 00:07:48,880
The server's not really doing much.

153
00:07:48,880 --> 00:07:52,376
Right?
My CPU is sitting at about 1% now.

154
00:07:52,376 --> 00:07:54,375
Most of that was me firing
up the task manager.

155
00:07:54,375 --> 00:07:57,757
I'm using a pittance of

695
00:34:19,410 --> 00:34:22,130
Databases do atomized transactions.

696
00:34:22,130 --> 00:34:24,560
So every time you write to a database,

697
00:34:24,560 --> 00:34:29,210
it has to ensure that the transaction
is safe, isolated, and

698
00:34:29,210 --> 00:34:36,240
protected from any other
transactions that are occurring.

699
00:34:36,240 --> 00:34:38,500
They call this process ACID.

700
00:34:38,500 --> 00:34:43,580
And ACID is an acronym, and again,

00:34:43,580 --> 00:34:48,190

00:34:48,190 --> 00:34:49,110

703
00:34:50,370 --> 00:34:56,200
ACID, it stands for Atomicity,
Consistency, Isolation, Durability.

704
00:34:56,200 --> 00:34:59,610
Every transaction performed
on a SQL server, or on MySQL,

705
00:34:59,610 --> 00:35:04,230
or Oracle, or whatever, tries to adhere
to these four characteristics, right?

706
00:35:04,230 --> 00:35:05,270
Atomicity.

707
00:35:05,270 --> 00:35:07,410
It's atomic,
that's what I was talking about.

708
00:35:07,410 --> 00:35:12,100
When you go to perform an activity, you're
making changes or you're querying data.

709
00:35:12,100 --> 00:35:15,700
You're working with a particular
set of information.

710
00:35:15,700 --> 00:35:16,520
That's atomic.

711
00:35:16,520 --> 00:35:20,670
It's a single component, and it has to
make sure that other people that are doing

712
00:35:20,670 --> 00:35:24,540
work on the server at the same time don't
mess with the data that you are getting.

713
00:35:24,540 --> 00:35:28,140
So when you go to work with it you grab
a single piece of that information, and

714
00:35:28,140 --> 00:35:29,760
it needs to be consistent.

715
00:35:29,760 --> 00:35:32,230
If you read that record right now, and

716
00:35:32,230 --> 00:35:35,810
you read that record two seconds from now,
it needs to have the same data.

717
00:35:35,810 --> 00:35:38,350
Or if five people read from
the same record at the same time,

718
00:35:38,350 --> 00:35:41,740
they all need to get the same data,
it needs to be consistent.

719
00:35:41,740 --> 00:35:42,790
Isolated.

720
00:35:42,790 --> 00:35:46,570
When I go to make a change,
it needs to protect the data so

721
00:35:46,570 --> 00:35:49,870
that if somebody else is making a change,
we don't bump into each other.

722
00:35:49,870 --> 00:35:54,690
Only one person can make a change at
a time to ensure proper isolation.

723
00:35:54,690 --> 00:35:56,010
And durability.

724
00:35:56,010 --> 00:35:59,450
When I make a change,
the change needs to stay,right?

725
00:35:59,450 --> 00:36:01,970
If I'm making five changes in a row and

726
00:36:01,970 --> 00:36:06,380
the fifth change breaks, I need to
roll back all five of those changes.

727
00:36:06,380 --> 00:36:07,740
They didn't work, right?

728
00:36:07,740 --> 00:36:09,450
My database needs to be durable.

729
00:36:09,450 --> 00:36:11,970
It needs to withstand failures like that.

730
00:36:11,970 --> 00:36:14,230
And that's what your transactions logs do,

00:36:14,230 --> 00:36:16,830
They're all working towards

Isolation and Durability.

01:05:27,580 --> 01:05:29,430

01:05:29,430 --> 01:05:33,631

01:05:33,631 --> 01:05:36,176

01:05:36,176 --> 01:05:37,770

01:05:38,281 --> 01:05:43,150

01:06:13,640 --> 01:06:18,310

01:06:19,090 --> 01:06:20,350

01:06:25,030 --> 01:06:28,300

01:06:28,300 --> 01:06:32,322

01:06:32,322 --> 01:06:36,400

01:06:36,400 --> 01:06:39,450

cecause it's having to query the system to

01:06:39,450 --> 01:06:41,140
put all this information together.

1332
01:06:41,140 --> 01:06:41,730
All right?

1333
01:06:41,730 --> 01:06:45,430
So, you really wanna minimize the amount

01:06:45,430 --> 01:06:48,360
really focus in on what it

01:06:48,360 --> 01:06:49,440

01:07:15,540 --> 01:07:19,430

01:07:19,430 --> 01:07:22,392

01:07:23,530 --> 01:07:25,660

01:07:25,660 --> 01:07:27,740

01:07:27,740 --> 01:07:32,730

01:07:32,730 --> 01:07:36,150

01:07:36,150 --> 01:07:38,390

01:07:38,390 --> 01:07:40,530

01:07:40,530 --> 01:07:42,380

01:07:42,380 --> 01:07:46,710
Well, SQL actually has a lot of this

1357
01:07:46,710 --> 01:07:51,040
In the database, we have something called

1358
01:07:51,040 --> 01:07:55,880
The dynamic management views are created
for us, we don't have to make them, and

1359
01:07:55,880 --> 01:07:57,720
what they are is they're tables.

1360
01:07:57,720 --> 01:08:01,170
They're tables in our database
that the system makes.

1361
01:08:01,170 --> 01:08:05,957
If I go under my server here, and
I go under human resources and

1362
01:08:05,957 --> 01:08:13,180

start to see a bunch of stuff in here.

1363
01:08:13,180 --> 01:08:17,518

sys.columns, sys.whatever,

1364
01:08:17,518 --> 01:08:19,389
there's a lot of stuff in here.

1365
01:08:19,389 --> 01:08:20,410
All right?

1366
01:08:20,410 --> 01:08:23,130
And then here's the sys DM ones,
these are the really useful ones.

1367
01:08:23,130 --> 01:08:26,560
Sys DMDB, sys DM exec, and so on.

1368
01:08:26,560 --> 01:08:27,320
What are these?

1369
01:08:27,320 --> 01:08:30,170
That's a lot of tables,
there's hundreds of them.

1370
01:08:30,170 --> 01:08:30,670
Right?

1371
01:08:31,670 --> 01:08:32,540
What are those?

1372
01:08:32,540 --> 01:08:34,245
And that's just for

1373
01:08:34,245 --> 01:08:36,000
that's not even counting

1374
01:08:36,000 --> 01:08:37,240
The server has them too.

1375
01:08:37,240 --> 01:08:40,050
So what those are, are virtual tables.

1376
01:08:40,050 --> 01:08:41,360
They're not real tables.

1377
01:08:41,360 --> 01:08:42,090
They're views.

1378
01:08:42,090 --> 01:08:45,180
There's no underlying table
data underneath them.

1379
01:08:45,180 --> 01:08:50,990
And when I query them, if I query one of
those tables, the table doesn't exist.

1380
01:08:50,990 --> 01:08:54,290
SQL will intercept my query and
say, oh you're looking for

1381
01:08:54,290 --> 01:08:56,550
this data, let me go and get it.

1382
01:08:56,550 --> 01:08:59,170
And it's almost entirely performance data.

1383
01:08:59,170 --> 01:09:02,588
So if I wanna pull up my deadlock list I
can query a dynamic management view for

1384
01:09:02,588 --> 01:09:05,570
deadlocks, and it'll go out and
figure it out for me right then and

1385
01:09:05,570 --> 01:09:08,140
present the data to me
as if it was a table.

1386
01:09:08,140 --> 01:09:08,649
All right?

1387
01:09:08,649 --> 01:09:09,920
Now, why would I do that?

1388
01:09:09,920 --> 01:09:12,390
Why wouldn't I just use any of the other
tools that we've talked about?

1389
01:09:12,390 --> 01:09:15,500
Well, these can be
queried programatically.

1390
01:09:15,500 --> 01:09:19,030
You can query them right through
Transact-SQL and get the data back.

1391
01:09:19,030 --> 01:09:22,280
You don't need any access
to the underlying OS.

1392
01:09:22,280 --> 01:09:24,182
You can do it entirely through SQL.

1393
01:09:24,182 --> 01:09:27,030
So the dynamic management
views are designed to give

1394
01:09:27,030 --> 01:09:31,460
a database administrator access to all the
performance information they could need

1395
01:09:31,460 --> 01:09:34,050
without having to rely on
Windows underneath it.

1396
01:09:34,050 --> 01:09:34,700
All right?

1397
01:09:34,700 --> 01:09:38,150
Now, there are hundreds of
dynamic management views, and for

1398
01:09:38,150 --> 01:09:40,930
the exam they don't expect
you to know all of them.

1399
01:09:40,930 --> 01:09:42,980
In fact they really don't even

1400
01:09:42,980 --> 01:09:45,630
They want you to know that dynamic
management views exist and

1401
01:09:45,630 --> 01:09:46,830
how they can be used.

1402
01:09:46,830 --> 01:09:47,460
All right?

1403
01:09:47,460 --> 01:09:50,570
But, a couple of things that I
would make sure to remember, and

1404
01:09:50,570 --> 01:09:53,050
again these'll be in my show notes so
you guys will have it.

1405
01:09:53,050 --> 01:09:57,020
But the dynamic management views
are really broken up into five categories.

1406
01:09:57,020 --> 01:09:57,670
All right?

1407
01:09:57,670 --> 01:10:02,606
Most of them will have a name
that starts like this, sys.dm_

1408
01:10:02,606 --> 01:10:06,320
something followed by another value.

1409
01:10:06,320 --> 01:10:07,310
All right?

1410
01:10:07,310 --> 01:10:11,470
So, sys.dm, that let's you know
that this is a system table or

1411
01:10:11,470 --> 01:10:15,210
view, DM, it's a dynamic management view.

1412
01:10:15,210 --> 01:10:16,110
All right?

1413
01:10:16,110 --> 01:10:18,550
The next value, underscore something.

1414
01:10:18,550 --> 01:10:21,930
That's the category of what you're
monitoring, and there's five categories,

1415
01:10:21,930 --> 01:10:26,370
exec, os, transaction, io, database.

1416
01:10:26,370 --> 01:10:27,840
All right?

1417
01:10:27,840 --> 01:10:31,770
After that, there'll be something specific
you're monitoring about that entry.

1418
01:10:31,770 --> 01:10:34,120
So for example, transactions.

1419
01:10:34,120 --> 01:10:39,410
If I'm monitoring for deadlocks, that's
gonna be underneath the transactions view.

1420
01:10:39,410 --> 01:10:42,787
So I'll see sys.dm_ tran_deadlocks.

1421
01:10:42,787 --> 01:10:46,502
I don't know if that's exactly it, but
it'll be named something like that.

1422
01:10:46,502 --> 01:10:48,380
All right?
That's how I know what that one is.

1423
01:10:48,380 --> 01:10:49,548
Or I do an example down here.

1424
01:10:49,548 --> 01:10:50,873
Sys.dm_os, right?

1425
01:10:50,873 --> 01:10:55,700
So I'm querying something

01:10:55,700 --> 01:10:57,920

01:10:57,920 --> 01:10:58,530
All right.

01:10:58,530 --> 01:11:02,360
How long am I having to wait for

1429
01:11:02,360 --> 01:11:04,520
I don't have to have access to the OS.

1430
01:11:04,520 --> 01:11:07,432
This dynamic management view will
find out that data for me and

1431
01:11:07,432 --> 01:11:09,730
present it to me in table format.

1432
01:11:09,730 --> 01:11:10,340
All right?

1433
01:11:10,340 --> 01:11:11,845
So that's how we can use these.

1434
01:11:11,845 --> 01:11:16,380
Exec,that's for
processes executing on the server.

1435
01:11:16,380 --> 01:11:20,430
If I'm running queries, stored procedures,
anything like that, anything that's being

1436
01:11:20,430 --> 01:11:25,640

I can query data on that.

1437
01:11:25,640 --> 01:11:28,150
OS, that's the underlying
operating system.

1438
01:11:28,150 --> 01:11:30,840
All the stuff that we pulled from

1439

1440
01:11:33,170 --> 01:11:35,417
The data is gonna be stored in there too.

1441
01:11:35,417 --> 01:11:38,954
Sys.dm_tran, that's for
our transactional information,

1442
01:11:38,954 --> 01:11:44,280
transactions being committed, successfully
finished, or rolled back, that failed.

1443
01:11:44,280 --> 01:11:45,516
Deadlocks will show up in there to,

1444
01:11:45,516 --> 01:11:47,425
cuz that's usually when we
have transaction issues.

1445
01:11:47,425 --> 01:11:52,060

1446
01:11:52,060 --> 01:11:54,870
As data is being sent in and
out of the database.

1447
01:11:54,870 --> 01:11:59,190
Typically, this is disk I/O, but

1448
01:11:59,190 --> 01:12:03,140

out of RAM falls under the I/O category.

1449
01:12:03,140 --> 01:12:07,590
And then, lastly sys.bm_db

01:12:07,590 --> 01:12:11,150

01:12:16,764 --> 01:12:20,665

01:27:18,810 --> 01:27:20,970
